headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Large Companies Prevail In U.S. Auction of Airwaves Taking advantage of rules intended to help the smallest telecommunications companies and bolster competition, the nation's largest wireless phone services and their partners are on the verge of winning scores of new licenses in a $17 billion auction of airwaves. The small companies that were supposed to have received special treatment to promote competition are complaining that they lost at the expense of giants like AT&T Wireless, Sprint PCS, VoiceStream and Cingular. Verizon Wireless, which refused to form a partnership with a small company, appears likely to pay the highest price. [Page A1.]

headline: January 21-27; Airwave Auction Ends
summary: The largest auction ever conducted by the Federal government ended with $17 billion in bids for a share of the airwaves, mostly from the nation's largest wireless telephone companies and their partners. Small entrepreneurs that were supposed to receive special treatment in order to encourage competition complained that the giants dominated the auction through alliances with startups. The big winner, and the only major company not to team up with a small business, was Verizon. It will pay almost $9 billion for more than 100 licenses, including two in New York for more than $4 billion. Stephen Labaton

headline: Verizon's Earnings Rise 1.3%; Sprint's Profit Is Down 11%
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 1.3 percent, while Sprint reported an 11 percent decline in profit. Verizon, which was formed in June when Bell Atlantic bought GTE, said profit from operations climbed to $2.11 billion, or 77 cents a share, compared with $2.08 billion, or 75 cents a share, in the period a year earlier as it spent more to add long-distance customers in New York and sell more data and wireless services. Fourth-quarter sales rose 6.7 percent, to $16.9 billion from $15.8 billion.

headline: VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS TAKES STEPS TO CUT COSTS
summary: Verizon Communications plans to cut some jobs, limit overtime and dismiss contractors in an effort to reduce costs, the company president, Lawrence T. Babbio Jr., said yesterday. Verizon will achieve 40 percent of the cuts by dropping contractors and reducing overtime, Mr. Babbio said. Much of the rest, the company said, will come through attrition, with some layoffs, although it declined to be more specific. Mr. Babbio said Verizon expected to have 6.4 million to 6.6 million long-distance customers nationwide by year-end, a rise of 31 percent to 35 percent from the 4.9 million at the end of 2000. Verizon started selling long-distance service in New York about a year ago and enrolled 1.4 million customers by December.

headline: Metro Business Briefing; NO VERIZON INCREASES
summary: In what consumer advocates hailed as a victory yesterday, Verizon New Jersey said it would not seek an increase in its basic service rate of $8.19 a month for local phone service or for add-on services like caller ID. Across the board, there will be no increases, said Dennis Bone, president of the company, which is based in Newark. In December, Verizon withdrew an application to the State Board of Public Utilities that if approved would have forced most residential callers to accept bundled service packages starting at $15 per month. Verizon did ask the utilities board yesterday to deregulate rates charged to businesses with more than one phone line, asserting that dozens of companies had expressed interest in providing such service and therefore the market was competitive. But Michael Schweder, president of AT&T New Jersey, said that only a handful of companies, including his own, actually provide business phone service in New Jersey, meaning that Verizon could raise rates significantly. Verizon also said yesterday that it would contribute $20 million to provide Internet access to schools and libraries. Steve Strunsky

headline: VERIZON BID RAISES QUESTIONS
summary: The Justice Department said yesterday that significant questions remained about whether Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, had proved that its dominant local network was open to competitors that provide high-speed data service in Massachusetts. Verizon is seeking clearance to begin selling long-distance voice and data service to its local customers in the state -- a $2 billion market. The Justice Department voiced its concern in a filing to the Federal Communications Commission, which will have final say on Verizon's bid for long-distance service. Department officials urged the F.C.C. to be cautious in resolving the application, which it must decide by April 16.

headline: METRO BRIEFING
summary: NEW YORK ALBANY: PANEL FAILS TO RESOLVE IMPASSE -- A bipartisan legislative committee, impaneled to reconcile Republican and Democratic versions of a women's health bill, has dissolved without an agreement. The chief sticking point is a requirement that insurers cover contraceptives, a provision that the Roman Catholic Church opposes. The Republican-controlled Senate has said any such bill must exempt religious groups from having to provide birth control services to their employees. The Democrat-controlled Assembly maintains that it will not countenance such an exemption. Fewer than a dozen such committees have been created in the last six years, but this is the first one that has come up empty-handed. Somini Sengupta (NYT) MANHATTAN: STATE OFFICIAL'S DAUGHTER CHARGED -- The daughter of State Comptroller H. Carl McCall was arrested last night and charged with larceny and issuing bad checks, the police said. The woman, Marcella McCall, 37, who lives on the Upper West Side and works for Verizon, was arrested at her workplace at 1095 Avenue of the Americas at 6:20 p.m., the police said. The larceny charge stems from Ms. McCall's using her corporate credit card for nonbusiness purposes, said Sgt. William Stiles, a police spokesman. Mr. McCall, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, would not comment on the arrest. Andy Newman (NYT)

headline: Metro Business Briefing; PENALTIES WAIVED
summary: The New York State Public Service Commission voted yesterday to waive $25.8 million in potential penalties that Verizon Communications faced for service failures in August and September. Verizon had requested the waivers, saying that an 18-day labor strike in August and the backlogs it caused had been responsible for the company's inability to meet the commission's standards for repairs, installations and other activities in those months. Under the commission's regulatory system, penalties, returned to customers as rebates, are imposed if Verizon does not meet various monthly, quarterly and annual performance requirements, though the penalties may be waived when the company shows that the shortfalls resulted from circumstances beyond its control. The commission denied additional waiver requests that Verizon had requested for reasons other than the strike. Verizon's penalties for the regulatory year ended Aug. 31 now total at least $17.6 million, much more than the total in each of the three previous regulatory years. Joseph P. Fried

headline: Another F.C.C. Clearance For Verizon Long-Distance
summary: Verizon Communications received approval yesterday from federal regulators to provide long-distance service in Massachusetts, bringing to five the number of states where large Bell local telephone companies can enter into the fast-changing long-distance communications business. The approval by the Federal Communications Commission of Verizon's request in Massachusetts comes after the F.C.C. approved similar petitions in New York, Texas, Kansas and Oklahoma. By next year, analysts expect that the Bell companies, created from the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the 1980's, could compete with AT&T and other long-distance companies in as many as 20 states.

headline: Metro Business Briefing; STATE STEPS INTO VERIZON DISPUTE
summary: New York State's Public Service Commission said yesterday that it would order Verizon New York and the Communications Workers of America to set up procedures for handling employee contentions of inaccuracies or falsifications in Verizon's service-performance reports to the state. The union has said the reports contain inaccuracies and ''direct falsification,'' basing its charge, in part, on complaints that workers phone in on a union hotline. The company has called the charge false and the complaints unsubstantiated. A commission spokesman, David C. Flanagan, said the parties were also to work out procedures to prevent retribution against hotline users. A union research director, Kenneth Peres, said that in ordering the parties to resolve the dispute instead of doing its own investigation, the commission would ''default on its responsibility.'' A Verizon spokesman, Mark Marchand, said the commission's staff had found the company's procedures ''adequate to prevent any significant misreporting.'' Joseph P. Fried

summary: Larceny and other charges against the daughter of H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, were dismissed yesterday and the court records sealed. headline: Software Failure Halts Big Board Trading for Over an Hour
summary: A failed software upgrade left investors unable to trade shares on the New York Stock Exchange for nearly an hour and a half yesterday morning. The shutdown, the second the exchange has suffered in three years, prevented many stocks from opening for trading. As a result, the exchange shut its trading floor at 10:10 a.m. Trading resumed in most stocks by 11:35 a.m., but shares in the most severely affected companies, including I.B.M. and Verizon Communications, did not open until the afternoon.

headline: Metro Business Briefing | Verizon's Plans For New Jersey
summary: Verizon Communications may ask in the next few weeks for New Jersey's endorsement of its plan to sell long-distance service in the state, an executive said yesterday. Verizon needs the endorsement of the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities and approval from the Federal Communications Commission to offer the service, the executive, Dennis M. Bone, said. Mr. Bone is state president of Verizon New Jersey. Verizon, which is based in New York, will file its application after state regulators complete a two-year examination of local-phone networks, perhaps within two weeks, Mr. Bone said.

headline: Metro Business Briefing | Telephone Access Fees Attacked
summary: State consumer advocates in New Jersey and New York urged on Monday that their states' telephone regulators cut the fees that Verizon Communications charges other companies needing access to its lines to provide competing local phone service. In New Jersey, Blossom A. Peretz, the ratepayer advocate, called on the Board of Public Utilities to reduce Verizon's charges for such access to less than $10 per line a month, from the $16.21 the board set in 1997. That fee was voided last year by a federal judge saying that they have been set in an arbitrary and capricious manner. Bruce Cohen, general counsel for Verizon New Jersey, said yesterday that Ms. Peretz was asking his company to ''subsidize our competitors'' by providing them access ''at a rate below our cost.'' In New York, the attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, urged the Public Service Commission to adopt access-fee cuts recommended by an administrative law judge. Cliff Lee, a Verizon New York spokesman, said his company would respond in a brief that it would submit to the commission. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Long-Distance Petition
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it had requested federal approval to offer long-distance service in Pennsylvania. Verizon is barred from offering long-distance and data services to its local customers unless it can prove that competition exists in the local telephone market. A Verizon spokesman said about one million telephone lines in Pennsylvania -- roughly 14 percent -- were served by competitors. The Federal Communications Commission must rule on the application within 90 days. The F.C.C. has cleared the way for the company to offer long-distance service in New York and Massachusetts. Verizon is also seeking clearance in Connecticut.

headline: Metro Business Briefing | Long-Distance Expansion
summary: Verizon Communications says it intends to seek approval from the Federal Communications Commission to provide long-distance phone service in New Jersey by the end of the year. Verizon, based in New York, made the announcement on Saturday in a wide-ranging statement on the anniversary of its formation by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE on June 30, 2000. Verizon and other companies derived from the breakup of AT&T in 1984 are barred from long-distance service until they can show regulators that their local calling markets are open to competition. Verizon expects to seek long-distance approvals this year in Rhode Island, New Hampshire and Vermont, said Ivette Mendez, a Verizon spokeswoman. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

headline: Those Charming Steeples Aren't So Quaint Anymore
summary: THE Connecticut skyline has always been defined by its church steeples, those towers that rise about the trees and give so many of the state's communities their charm. But in a 21st century twist, these old spires that were originally built to resemble Christopher Wren's stone steeples in London are becoming the camouflage to hide microwave antennas for cell phone companies. What started slowly just a few years ago is becoming much more common, with church after church in town after town turning over the rooftops to the telephone companies. In return, cash-strapped churches not only receive monthly rent from the companies, but also get their steeples, often in desperate need of repairs, renovated for free. It is a gift many churches just can't pass up. ''We are a very poor church, trying our best to help the people in the community,'' said the Rev. Allison B. Cook of St. James Episcopal Church in Derby, where Verizon Wireless installed an antenna in 1997. ''This was, for us, a gift. And it was going to go somewhere.'' Despite concerns about the health effects of microwave radiation and the queasiness over letting commercial ventures use their space, about 20 churches have cut deals with the phone companies and more are in negotiation.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Ericsson Wins Verizon Order
summary: The Swedish phone equipment maker Ericsson will supply Verizon Wireless, the biggest United States mobile phone operator, with wireless handsets that allow high-speed access to the Web, e-mail and other services. The two companies are testing new handsets that use code-division multiple access, or C.D.M.A., technology to increase the transmission capacity of digital networks. Ericsson says its C.D.M.A. handsets transmit information at up to 144 kilobits a second. Most current cell phones run wireless Web applications at around 11 kilobits a second. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: Footlights
summary: All This Jazz Playing jazz, talking about jazz and evoking jazz through photographs are all on the schedule at Columbia University as part of the 2001 Verizon Music Festival. On Friday from 9 a.m to 6:30 p.m. in room 312 of the university's Mathematics Building, a symposium of jazz scholars, musicians, poets and photographers will consider ''The Sources of Jazz,'' and from tomorrow through Aug. 23, the LeRoy Neiman Gallery in Dodge Hall will be the site of ''Jazz in the City: New Orleans and Harlem,'' a show of jazz photographs by Michael P. Smith and Gerald Cyrus. On Saturday, as the closing attraction, a free outdoor concert from 4 to 9 p.m. in the Columbia Quadrangle at 116th Street and Broadway will feature the vocalist Abby Lincoln, the Wayne Shorter Quartet, the James Carter Chasin' the Gypsy Band and the Big 3 Palladium Orchestra, with Tito Puente Jr., among others.

summary: Verity Inc., a maker of search-engine software that had been forecasting a fiscal first-quarter profit, said it now expects a loss as a result of reduced orders by its customers, which include AT&T Wireless and Verizon Communications. headline: Author and Telephone Repairman Finds Art in Imitating His Life
summary: Whatever the merits of that well-worn advice to aspiring authors to ''write what you know,'' it's guidance that Michael Ledwidge of Kingsbridge has clearly taken to heart. Mr. Ledwidge, 30, wrote ''Bad Connection,'' a thriller published by Pocket Books in April that features an Irish-American telephone cable splicer from the Bronx who roams Midtown climbing into manholes to fix phone lines. Mr. Ledwidge happens to be an Irish-American splicer who repairs phone lines for Verizon in Midtown. Mr. Ledwidge wrote his first crime novel, ''The Narrowback,'' published in 1999 and reissued in April in paperback by Pocket, while working the night shift as a doorman and freight elevator operator at a luxury apartment building at East 58th Street and Park Avenue. That book, by the way, features a blue-collar Irish-American protagonist and starts off at a luxury Midtown hotel.

headline: 5 Groups in 6 Hours, From the 30's to the 90's
summary: Musical eras flashed by and intermingled like happily jumbled memories at the Verizon Jazz Festival's finale, a free concert Saturday afternoon on the Columbia University campus. The 1930's, 50's, 60's and 90's were all up for grabs as five first-rate groups appeared during the six-hour concert. The saxophonist Wayne Shorter's quartet was back in New York after a JVC Jazz Festival appearance, and it had been honed by touring in between. Mr. Shorter's 1960's and 70's compositions are revered in modern jazz, and his new quartet revisits those pieces by shattering and reassembling them. Where Mr. Shorter once wrote songful melodies and richly devious harmonies, his new quartet also works with moods, juxtapositions and a rigorous sense of flux. The music was always headed somewhere new.

headline: Metro Business Briefing | AT&T To Add Monthly Charge
summary: Beginning on Sept. 1, AT&T will add a monthly charge of $1.35 for in-state long-distance service to most residential customers' bills, the company has said. It said the charge was needed because it had to pay fees to local phone companies, predominantly Verizon, for access to networks to complete in-state long-distance calls. A Verizon spokeswoman, Ivette Mendez, said yesterday that there was no justification for the fee increase because the access fees Verizon charges have gone down. The disagreement is the latest in a dispute between AT&T and Verizon over fees AT&T pays to use Verizon's system. AT&T customers whose long-distance bills are less than $1 will not have to pay the new fee, nor will customers in its program for low-income customers. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline: Joan Keating and James Durning
summary: FAMILY ties do bind, but sometimes in unexpected ways. In August 1996, Joan Carole Keating, now 40, was invited by an old pal, Eileen Brady, to spend the weekend at a large share house in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. There she noticed James Richard Durning, 39, a friend of Ms. Brady's husband, Steve Geary. Initially, Ms. Keating, who is divorced, thought the woman with Mr. Durning was a date. But when Ms. Keating and Mr. Durning, a field technician for Verizon, started talking, she learned the woman was his cousin, Deirdre Durning. By the wee hours of the morning, Ms. Keating and Mr. Durning were swimming in the pool overlooking Aspatuck Creek.

headline: Using a Cellphone Signal to Hunt For a Victim in Desperate Need
summary: SOME people in or near Lower Manhattan were surprised last week when they turned on their cellphones and were almost immediately called by their wireless carriers. The companies, it turns out, were monitoring cellular signals near the collapsed World Trade Center towers to try to find survivors who might have been trapped or were otherwise unaccounted for. Pinpointing the location from which a cellphone might be transmitting is far from an exact science, but any signals in the area were reason for hope. After a week, however, the search operations of companies like AT&T Wireless and Verizon Wireless proved fruitless.

headline: Saving Precious Voice Mail
summary: One of the first things Verizon Communications officials did after the World Trade Center attack upon arriving at their heavily damaged switching station at 140 West Street was to begin preserving the voice mail system that serves thousands of local customers. On Friday, Verizon asked voice mail customers todelete messages they did not need, in order to avoid overtaxing the system. What Verizon did not say was that it wanted as many messages discarded as possible so it could turn off the so-called electronic janitor that automatically deletes messages, and allow people to retain last-minute messages they received from loved ones who may have perished in the twin towers, according to Eric Rabe, the chief spokesman for Verizon.

headline: Phone Providers Near Ground Zero Are Still Frantically Scrambling to Catch Up
summary: At 5:20 p.m. on Sept. 11, telephone service in Lower Manhattan was knocked out when a 47-story World Trade Center building toppled onto a Verizon telephone center on West Street. Cellular antennas and data lines had already been out; now, all of a sudden, land lines went, too, and everyone from court officials to F.B.I. agents were scrambling to get phone service. More than three weeks later, it is clear that some solutions emerged quickly, and also that the easy part is over, with the hard part just beginning. The damaged Verizon building, a switching center in a 32-story Art Deco building on West Street, has equipment in five sub-basements that were flooded by a water-main break and firefighting efforts even before 7 World Trade Center collapsed into the side of the building, ripping gaping holes into walls lined with millions of dollars in equipment.

headline: CENTURYTEL BUYING 675,000 VERIZON PHONE LINES
summary: CenturyTel Inc., which sells local and wireless phone service in 21 states, agreed to buy about 675,000 telephone lines in Alabama and Missouri from Verizon Communications Inc. for $2.16 billion. The transaction expands CenturyTel's local-phone market in rural regions by 37 percent, and lets Verizon focus on selling phone service mostly in metropolitan areas, Verizon said. The additional lines are expected to generate $530 million to $550 million in annual revenue, and per-share earnings of 4 cents to 7 cents in the first year, CenturyTel said. The company, which is based in Monroe, La., is getting lines in growing cities like Branson, Mo., and Dothan, Ala. Verizon, which is based in New York, said in September it wanted to sell 1.2 million rural phone lines in Alabama, Kentucky and Missouri.

headline: Footlights
summary: On the Move Since 1908 the Philadelphia Orchestra has been planning to leave its home, the Academy of Music, which was designed for opera. On Saturday the dream will come true when Wolfgang Sawallisch leads the ensemble in its inaugural concert in the new $265 million, 2,500-seat Verizon Hall. Designed by Rafael Viñoly, the hall occupies an entire block -- 2.3 acres -- in the heart of Philadelphia. Saturday's concert is to include the world premiere of a piece by Aaron Jay Kernis commissioned for the occasion, and on Sunday comes the official opening, a daylong open house featuring an assortment of free performances. Besides housing the Philadelphia Orchestra, Verizon Hall will be home the Philly Pops, and its 650-seat Perelman Theater will be home to Philadanco, the Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia, the Philadelphia Chamber Music Society and American Theater Arts for Youth. Information: (215) 893-1999. Winners In 1926 Walter Naumburg, an investment banker and amateur cellist, established the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation to offer young musicians assistance and give them recognition by presenting them in recitals. At 7:30 p.m. Thursday at Alice Tully Hall, the Naumburg Foundation will celebrate its 75th anniversary with a gala concert featuring past Naumburg winners, including the foundation's president, Robert Mann (1941). Among other scheduled performers are the Emerson String Quartet, the Eroica Trio, Leonid Hambro, Anthony Molinaro, Joseph Silverstein, Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, Dawn Upshaw and Carol Wincenc. Information: (212) 875-5050.

headline: The Good, the Bad and the Totally Arbitrary
summary: Few employees can escape the annual performance review. It is a ritual of appraisal of performance and achievement of goals that is approached with dread -- sometimes by the reviewer, too. Now come these reviews of the review process. Alan Heisey, who now publishes a consumer magazine and a newspaper for the construction industry in Toronto, recalls a manager whose oral evaluation of his work many years ago was more than generous. The evaluation came while Mr. Heisey was a material control supervisor for a television manufacturing factory. He recalls the manager saying, ''If you aren't the best man who ever worked for me, you are one of the best, and I am glad I've got you.'' Mr. Heisey writes, ''That kind of praise has never occurred before or since, but it is memorable, I think, particularly because he fired me a month later.'' ''Annual appraisals for staffers in hundreds of diverse field offices across the country were a huge problem for my company,'' writes George Zucker of Haverford, Pa., remembering his days as a journalist. ''They were still working on it when I retired. ''Our personnel mavens didn't want appraisals heavy on praise and light on red flags. 'We don't become a great company by telling each other how great we are,' was an oft-quoted adage.'' He added: ''The problem was finding credible ways to grade outstanding staffers. Good people expect good reviews and can be overly sensitive to negative feedback. They might quit to find more appreciation elsewhere. ''One year the field managers were ordered to rank each of our staffers numerically. It was a disaster, and the personnel chief was livid when the managers were called to New York the next year for a post-mortem.'' As Mr. Zucker recalls it, the personnel chief ticked off some of the failures of the new system and then looked directly at Mr. Zucker as he said: ''One manager had half his staff ranked in the top 10. How can you do that?'' Mr. Zucker said he replied, ''I had a bunch tied for No. 1.'' There were no rankings after that. ''I am a human resources professional, so you would think that we would treat our own as we preach,'' says Sharon Scheirer, the human resources director at the Equinox Resort in Manchester, Vt. ''One of the positions I held was as a regional manager for a Fortune 500 company. My boss, the vice president for human relations, was located in the Midwest. One day, after my first anniversary, a confidential envelope arrived with my name on it. Surprise! It was my performance review, thanking me for my excellent work during the year. No discussion, no notice that the review was on the way -- just a one-sided appraisal with some dollars attached. ''I now use this example of how not to do it when coaching managers during performance appraisal training.'' ''I have been on both sides of the performance review process, the giver and the receiver,'' writes Joseph Stagnitta of Hyde Park, N.Y., a retired product manager in the world trade division of I.B.M. ''And yes, the task can be dreaded by both parties.'' One time, he said, he was surprised to receive a performance review based on a one-week-old plan ''delinquently submitted by my then current manager.'' ''I challenged the appraisal,'' he added, ''and it was escalated to higher management, which upheld my position that the appraisal was not fair. ''Then, in another instance I had an opportunity to provide the surprise when I declined signing an agreement about my performance review when, in response to my inquiry about what I need to do to improve my rating even further, I was told, 'Walk on water.' ''From that point on, I never rated my company a '1' in the annual opinion surveys, at least not till they showed me how they could walk on water.'' ''As a career changer, I was used to political performance reviews to keep me under the glass ceiling for my age,'' writes Karen S. Kendler, a computer consultant and freelance writer from Riverdale, the Bronx. ''However, one of the worst I ever had was one where my manager forced me to give low priority to technical growth as a career growth objective and then gave me performance feedback indicating I needed to concentrate more on technical growth. ''Damned if you do and damned if you don't.'' Kevin C. Naff of Baltimore, now a manager of business development at Verizon Wireless, knows what to do when he wants a good laugh. He pulls out a review he received seven years ago. While working as an assistant editor for a business trade magazine, he writes, he reported to an editor who was ''one of those types who feels obligated to nit-pick only so she can remind you who's in charge.'' ''She presented my review, which told glowing tales of my superior, flawless performance,'' he recalled. ''Then I turned the page. There, under the section titled 'Needs Improvement,' she wrote: 'Kevin needs to inprove his poofereading skills.' '' Mr. Naff is still laughing.

headline: Fair Local Phone Rates
summary: The New York Public Service Commission helped jump-start competition for local phone service yesterday when it ordered Verizon to further discount the wholesale rate at which it leases its lines to competing companies trying to enter the New York market. The move is not only beneficial to state consumers; it could be of vital importance to the nation's overall economy. In recent years, healthy competition has revolutionized the market for many telecommunications products, from long distance to cellphone services. Local service, however, remains a near-monopoly, firmly in the hands of the Baby Bells, including Verizon, that were created by the breakup of AT&T in 1984 and control the ''last mile'' of wire into consumers' homes and offices. Nationwide, competitors to the Baby Bells provide local service to less than 10 percent of all phone lines, and only 5 percent of all residential lines.

headline: VERIZON REPORTS FOURTH-QUARTER LOSS OF $2 BILLION
summary: Verizon Communications, the nation's biggest local telephone company, posted a $2 billion fourth-quarter loss because of investment declines and costs to eliminate 8,700 jobs. The loss, 75 cents a share, was in contrast to net income of $1.9 billion, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose less than 1 percent, to $17 billion. The number of local phone lines dropped for a third quarter as corporate layoffs crimped demand and consumers relied more on mobile phones. Phone lines in service fell 2.1 percent, to 61.6 million. Expenses included $1.93 billion from a decline in the value of investments, including Verizon's stake in Genuity Inc. It also had $1 billion in severance costs.

summary: ValueClick, an online advertising company, agreed to buy Be Free Inc. for about $128.5 million in stock. Shareholders of Be Free will own about 45 percent of the combined company's shares outstanding; the deal is expected to be completed by the end of the second quarter. headline: Rating Services' Doubts Hurt Shares of Verizon
summary: The bond and share prices of Verizon Communications Inc. fell yesterday after two credit ratings services said the company needed to reduce its dependence on volatile short-term borrowing or increase its bank commitments backing that debt. Verizon, which has $12.8 billion in debt that matures in less than nine months, may see its financing costs rise if it shifts to more expensive longer-term notes. Dennis Saputo, an analyst for one rating firm, Moody's Investors Service, said Verizon had backed its short-term debt with $8.5 billion of cash and bank credit commitments, which might not be enough.

headline: Verizon Shifts Debt To Longer Terms
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it sold $1.5 billion of bonds with maturities as long as 30 years. Credit-rating companies have recently said the company relied too much on short-term debt. Verizon sold $1 billion of 10-year notes and $500 million of 30-year bonds through its New York unit in a sale planned for the past month, said Fred Salerno, the chief financial officer. The company is borrowing to reduce $12.8 billion in debt maturing in nine months or less.

headline: Defaults Seem Near for Latin Units of BellSouth and Verizon
summary: The BellSouth Corporation and Verizon Communications, two of the largest telephone companies, signaled yesterday that their Latin American operations were preparing to default on hundreds of millions of dollars of debt because of economic problems in Brazil and Argentina. The defaults would be further evidence of a shift in the business climate in South America. Foreign utilities that leapt into the region's economies in the 1990's when they opened their markets to competition have had problems after policy changes and less generous international borrowing markets limited chances for profitability.

headline: Verizon Wireless Sues U.S. Over Licenses
summary: Verizon Wireless Inc. has sued the federal government in an effort to cancel an $8.7 billion agreement to buy wireless licenses. The carrier, in a filing, asked the Court of Federal Claims to force the government to return the remaining $261 million of a $1.7 billion down payment for the licenses and compensate the company for lost interest while the Federal Communications Commission held the money. Verizon Wireless has said it may be owed more than $100 million in interest.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Metromedia Fiber Defaults On Payment
summary: The data cable company Metromedia Fiber Network Inc. said yesterday that it had defaulted on a $30 million debt interest payment to Verizon Communications Inc. It was the second time this month Metromedia, which is controlled by the billionaire John W. Kluge, missed a debt payment. The provider of links for Internet companies including AOL Time Warner Inc. averted bankruptcy last year by securing $611 million of financing, which included a $150 million note from Citigroup Inc. and a $230 million note convertible into stock. The company is discussing a restructuring agreement with bondholders and may seek Chapter 11 protection from creditors if no agreement is reached. A 30-day grace period for the interest owed on $975 million of debt lapsed yesterday, a Metromedia spokeswoman said. Metromedia, which operates fiber optic networks in cities including New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, defaulted April 1 on $8.1 million owed to Nortel Networks.

headline: Bypassing the Carriers, a Burg Goes Broadband
summary: DURING the Civil War, Cumberland built a fort on the hill overlooking the center of town as a bulwark against the Confederate forces just across the Potomac. Today, the city is trying to use the same high ground to strategic advantage in a different campaign: keeping pace with the Internet age. After years of waiting for the phone company, Verizon, to offer high-speed Internet service here, the local government wants to take on the job. And the hill above downtown, now the site of Fort Hill High School, has already proved to be an opportune spot for a crucial station relaying Internet traffic.

headline: Pension Folly: How Losses Become Profits
summary: IN the land of executive compensation, there is nothing like being paid for profits that you can be sure will be counted, even if they do not exist. Why take chances with real earnings? Last year, Verizon Communications reported net income of $389 million after taking losses for a variety of things, among them investments in Metromedia Fiber Network, a company whose shares have plunged from a peak of more than $50 to less than 5 cents. Top officers' bonuses were reduced but not eliminated.

So it will be a refreshing change for Mr. Seidenberg to accept an honor.

headline: Telecommunications Issues Fall Sharply
summary: Investors in the troubled telecommunications sector stepped up their pace to the exits yesterday. The hardest hit were Qwest Communications International and WorldCom, two concerns with heavy debt loads and enough questions about their accounting to be the subjects of investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But companies like Verizon Communications, SBC Communications and BellSouth, which had fared well by comparison this year, also sagged under the selling pressure yesterday.

headline: Investing; Where Telecom Bargain Hunters Turn
summary: IT has been two months since Ivan G. Seidenberg, the chief executive of Verizon Communications, mused at an investment conference that his company might bid for WorldCom ''for the fun of it'' if the stock price of that long-distance and Internet carrier continued falling. Since then, WorldCom's shares have dropped 80 percent, to $1.58 on Friday. But as Mr. Seidenberg wryly suggested, conditions in the communications sector are so tough that Verizon has no real interest in WorldCom at any price. Verizon, along with rivals like SBC Communications, BellSouth and Deutsche Telekom, all have plenty of their own problems without taking on WorldCom's, which include gigantic debt and an accounting investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Dig It
summary: For about 300 years, Murray Street was a street. Then, last winter, after the World Trade Center went down, it was dug up and turned into a hole. Not a little hole. Not a hole with a few flags and two or three workers and a blinking yellow light. The hole that was Murray Street was a crumbling and steaming and wooden-plank-reinforced earthen gash, which, if it weren't lying sideways across the border of TriBeCa and the financial district, would have been about 100 stories tall. In January, on a cold, clear morning, just after the underground version of Murray Street had been opened up, Mike Redes, a project manager for Empire City Subway, a Verizon-owned company that maintains utilities under the street, was standing on a single-family-home-size plot of subterranean real estate in which Murray Street meets Church Street. Over the previous several weeks, the area had been excavated nearly in its entirety, revealing an open stream of cables and conduits, pipes and mains that separated the former World Trade Center from the rest of Manhattan like a moat. As Redes stood there, as he waved his arm and pointed into the man-cut crevasse, men with short shovels were scrambling into the hole, tossing up steaming dirt. ''What the heck am I gonna do?'' he says. ''I've got to put a manhole in!'' (A manhole is a vault that allows technicians to gain access to underground cables without tearing up the street. The entrance is covered by, yes, a manhole cover.)

headline: Kathryn Whipple, Mark Raimy
summary: Kathryn Elizabeth Whipple, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce R. Whipple of West Pittston, Pa., was married yesterday to Mark Harvey Raimy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce H. Raimy of Erie, Pa. The Rev. William Bergen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. Mrs. Raimy, 29, is an Internet specialist in New York for McKinsey & Company, the management consulting concern. She graduated and received a master's degree in higher education from Pennsylvania State University. Her father retired as a fiber-optics service technician in the Wilkes-Barre, Pa., office of Verizon, the telephone company. Her mother, Gert Dwyer Whipple, is an assistant vice president and the manager of residential mortgage sales in Wilkes-Barre for M&T Bank.

headline: Maruyama's a Winner, and Crane Feels Like One
summary: Shigeki Maruyama won a tournament today, but the runner-up, Ben Crane, felt as if he had won the lottery. On a day when the biggest stars in the Verizon Byron Nelson Classic were overshadowed, Maruyama and Crane capitalized on opportunities to take their careers to another level. Maruyama, possessing an infectious smile and a creative short game, became the first Asian-born player to win twice on the PGA Tour. And Crane, a 26-year-old rookie, secured his Tour card for next year, shooting a sensational five-under-par 65 that vaulted him into second place.

headline: Critic's Notebook; Carnegie Hall vs. the Kimmel Center
summary: When the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia opened in December, work on Verizon Hall, the new 2,500-seat home of the Philadelphia Orchestra, the largest component of the center, was barely complete. With its unusual shape, somewhat like a cello, its airy ambience, beautiful wood paneling and velour seat covers, Verizon Hall immediately felt like an inviting space to hear a concert. But you were reluctant to place your hand on a railing for fear of getting smudged with wet varnish. The air-conditioning system was stuck on high, and the hall was freezing. Given this, many critics and concertgoers were hesitant about making a pronouncement on the question that mattered most: How are the acoustics?

summary: Verizon Information Services in Dallas, a division of Verizon Communications, said yesterday that it had selected Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, part of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network, to handle the account for the SuperPages yellow pages directory and an online directory, SuperPages .com. Billings were estimated at $30 million to $40 million. headline: Music by Any Name: Live, From Mahler Hall
summary: To the Editor: Re ''What's in a Name?'' (editorial, May 23): Perhaps the problem of naming a new or renovated home for the New York Philharmonic is actually an opportunity. The latest techniques in architectural acoustics, as used in Philadelphia's new Verizon Hall, allow architects to build rooms with variable acoustics. Movable ceiling panels and detachable reverberant chambers enable conductors to adjust the sound to fit the particular music being performed.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protest Set For Verizon Headquarters
summary: The communications workers union has scheduled a demonstration today in front of Verizon's headquarters to protest what it says are plans to lay off 2,100 workers in New York State. The protest is scheduled for 5 p.m. on 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas. The union says such layoffs would violate its contract, but Verizon officials deny planning layoffs in New York. headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Sues Verizon Over Layoffs
summary: The union representing employees at Verizon asked a federal judge yesterday to temporarily stop Verizon from dismissing 2,100 telecommunications workers who could be laid off by summer's end. Verizon has proposed reducing its work force through voluntary and involuntary measures. But the union, the Communications Workers of America, said such cutbacks would hurt customer service, including lengthening repair time for damaged phone lines. Under the union contract, Verizon must declare a ''surplus'' of workers before layoffs can begin. ''We are claiming that the surplus is not only not real, but that this will do tremendous harm,'' said Gay Semel, a union attorney. John J. Bonomo, a Verizon spokesman, said there was no merit to the lawsuit. Jayson Blair (NYT)

headline: Verizon Reverses Increase at Some Pay Phones
summary: Verizon Communications officials said yesterday that they had decided to reverse a recent rate increase on thousands of pay phones in New York City, meaning that many phones will require only 25 cents for calls, instead of 50 cents. The company began switching back 14,000 pay phones on sidewalks, in subway stations and at other locations on Monday. The 25-cent rate for a four-minute call is the same that existed in March, before Verizon changed the price to 50 cents for a call of unlimited time. This is the first time that Verizon, which operates pay phones in dozens of markets, has reversed a pay phone rise.

headline: Footlights
summary: Coming Attraction Masterpieces by Goya, El Greco and Murillo are to be exhibited at the Alexandria Museum of Art in Alexandria, La., beginning on Sept. 30, 2003, during the Louisiana Purchase Bicentennial, under an agreement signed last week in Washington by state and Spanish officials. The exhibition, ''The Heart of Spain,'' will include pre-Christian, Byzantine, Roman and Gothic art and works from the 18th and 19th centuries, when Spain's influence in Louisiana was substantial. Season's Greetings Summer, unofficially in progress since the Memorial Day weekend, is actually about to arrive, and there are those who stand ready to celebrate. In New York, where the season begins at 9:24 a.m. Friday, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine will present ''Paul Winter's Ninth Annual Summer Solstice Celebration.'' In Philadelphia, the new Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts will party all night. Sessions of celebration at St. John the Divine, built around African-inspired music, are scheduled for 7:30 p.m. on Friday and Saturday, and for those who like an early start on a really long day, for 4:30 a.m. Saturday. In Philadelphia a ticket to ''Summer Solstice Celebration,'' beginning at 8 p.m. Friday, includes access to 12 hours of entertainment at various sites in the Kimmel Center, ending with a sunrise ceremony under its 150-foot glass ceiling and a gospel performance in Verizon Hall.

headline: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Inquiry Into Verizon Marketing
summary: Federal regulators are investigating whether Verizon Communications illegally marketed its long-distance service in New Jersey before receiving government permission to sell it there. On Monday, the Federal Communications Commission announced that it had approved Verizon's petition to enter the New Jersey market. In May, Verizon said that one of its direct-marketing companies accidentally sent out a mailing urging New Jersey residents to buy its long distance service. But a rival, A T & T Corporation, complained that Verizon had also included long-distance advertisements in Verizon local-service bills sent to more than 500,000 New Jersey customers. Verizon has agreed to send letters to customers informing them that the F.C.C. had not yet approved Verizon's application. If the F.C.C. decides against Verizon, it could impose a hefty fine or even revoke the company's license for New Jersey's $2.2 billion long-distance market. Jayson Blair (NYT)

headline: VERIZON WIRELESS TO GIVE $600 MILLION IN DISCOUNTS
summary: Verizon Wireless Inc. agreed to provide as much as $600 million in discounts to settle a lawsuit with customers nationwide who had claimed that the company hid service charges. Cell-phone customers sued Verizon and its predecessors two years ago in California State Superior Court in San Diego, claiming they did not fully explain special offers and hidden charges for rounding up calls to minute increments, operator assistance, busy signals, service switching, contract cancellation and local and long-distance tolls. Verizon denies the allegations in the lawsuit and plans to issue ''a new, uniform customer agreement'' approved by the plaintiffs' lawyers, according to the company's Web site and documents mailed to customers this week.

headline: A Wireless 911 System Finds Those in Need
summary: AS an elderly couple drove through southwestern Illinois last fall, their car suddenly caught fire. They had no idea where they were, even what county they were in, said the local director of 911 services, Norm Forshee. Luckily, though, they were in St. Clair County, the first county in the nation to install an advanced cellphone-locator system for its emergency service. When the couple called 911, dispatchers pinpointed where they were, and help arrived a few minutes later. This is one of the success stories to emerge since last October, when St. Clair County and Verizon Wireless introduced the first enhanced 911 system for wireless phones. Now any 911 call made in the county by a Verizon customer or someone roaming on Verizon's network can be located to within about 300 feet, and often even closer.

summary: The city's redistricting commission met for the first time yesterday. The commission, which must reflect a certain political and geographic balance, elected Henry M. Calderon, a Republican mayoral appointee, as chairman. headline: REGIONAL MARKET: The Bronx; Fordham Revival Where Alexander's Once Ruled
summary: A large Caldor sign still sits atop the five-story building at 2 Fordham Square on the northwest corner of Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, even though Caldor vacated the 300,000-square-foot building in 1997, two years after it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Before Caldor moved into the building, in 1993, 2 Fordham Square was occupied by Alexander's department store, which declared bankruptcy in 1992. A white elephant for the better part of a decade, the building was bought by Fordham Associates in January 2001 for $25 million in cash from Vornado, the national real estate investment trust. Since then, nine tenants have signed leases of 10 to 20 years, including four that are already open on street level. The three on the Fordham Road side of the building are North Fork Bank (with 3,500 square feet), Verizon Wireless (1,800 square feet) and The Children's Place (5,500 square feet). Seagull Fashions (2,800 square feet), a women's apparel shop on the Creston Avenue side of the building, is also open.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: CenturyTel Completes Sale Of Wireless Unit
summary: CenturyTel Inc., which sells telephone service in 22 states, yesterday completed the sale of its mobile-phone business to its rival, the Alltel Corporation, for $1.65 billion. The sale lets CenturyTel focus on selling local and Internet services, the company said in a statement. Alltel will bill customers under the CenturyTel name until it completes a billing system conversion later this year. CenturyTel agreed in March to sell the business to Alltel after spurning its $9.2 billion offer for all of CenturyTel. Alltel yesterday also completed the purchase of 600,000 local phone lines in Kentucky from Verizon Communications, the largest American local-phone company, for $1.9 billion. The acquisition increases the Alltel's local-phone lines to more than three million, the company said. Shares of CenturyTel fell 30 cents, to $26.30. They had fallen 19 percent this year. Alltel dropped 32 cents, to $40.20.

headline: Pulling Communications Into the 21st Century
summary: LONG ISLAND may be making progress in attracting high-tech companies, but the failure to modernize telecommunications at the region's largest business park bodes ill for the region's future and tarnishes its image, the park's tenants and building owners say. Now, a group of executives and owners at the complex, Hauppauge Industrial Park, have abandoned efforts to convince Lightpath and Verizon to revamp the rat's nest of aging cables lying underneath the buildings and instead are looking to wireless technology as a solution. Several people involved with those efforts say they are close to announcing a pilot project that will solve what is called the ''last mile'' problem, bridging the gap between the national broadband cable network and the buildings in the park.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Genuity Gets Extension To Renegotiate Credit Line
summary: Genuity, a seller of high-speed Internet access that defaulted last month on $3 billion in loans, says lenders have given it 30 more days to renegotiate the credit line. As part of the ''standstill'' agreement, the second since July 29, Genuity will pay $50 million, according to a statement. The company also said it would no longer finance Integra, a manager of data for corporate Web sites that is 93 percent owned by Genuity. Last month, Verizon Communications chose not to buy a controlling stake in Genuity, causing a default under the company's credit agreement. The new accord gives Genuity time to renegotiate repayment of the loans. Genuity, based in Woburn, Mass., has drawn down $1.87 billion of a $2 billion credit line from banks, as well as a $1.15 billion loan from Verizon, a spokeswoman, Susan Kraus, said. Verizon had made $2 billion available, but it said last month that it would not extend the remaining $850 million, Ms. Kraus said. On July 29, Genuity said it had been given two weeks to renegotiate its credit line. Under that agreement, Genuity paid $100 million.

headline: ON THE GROUND: Newark; A Gateway to New York Is Enjoying a Renaissance
summary: Newark -- a 15-minute train ride from Manhattan -- is a leading gateway to New York. But this third-oldest major American city has been enjoying a renaissance, and there are several reasons to stay in town. Newark is aggressively fighting to eradicate its reputation for crime; in fact, crime has decreased more than 50 percent in the last six years. In recent years there has also been an influx of businesses, including the IDT Corporation, MBNA and the SBLI USA Mutual Life Insurance Company, which join stalwarts like Verizon, PSE&G, Merrill Lynch and Horizon Blue Cross and Blue Shield. The city has begun an effort to revitalize its waterfront, with the Faneuil Hall area of Boston and South Street Seaport in Manhattan as models. The F.B.I. will become the first organization to establish a presence there when construction is completed on its new office building.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: AOL To Use Covad High-Speed Network
summary: Covad Communications said yesterday that AOL Time Warner would use Covad's network to provide high-speed Web connections to America Online customers. The five-year agreement gives AOL Time Warner, based in New York, access to a network covering 40 million homes and businesses in the United States, Covad said in a statement. Shares of Covad, which emerged from bankruptcy in December, rose as much as 29 percent, before ending the day at $1.32, up 18 cents, or 15.8 percent. As the number of new consumers using dial-up Internet access slows, AOL Time Warner is trying to add customers through agreements with companies like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications, which have regional high-speed networks. Covad sells high-speed links to the Internet through digital subscriber lines. AOL Time Warner will pay Covad an undisclosed amount a month for each subscriber. A Covad spokeswoman, Martha Sessums, declined to give the amount. An AOL Time Warner spokesman, Ed Adler, did not return phone calls seeking comment.

headline: A Relaxed Tony Bennett Is a Master of Surprise
summary: Tony Bennett is not a vocalist given to pumping personal psychodrama into a song. A supremely confident swinger, he would rather play the genially reverent custodian of the American popular songbook, concentrating on the pleasure to be found in his material. He is so comfortable on the stage that he makes relaxation and rhythmic command appear synonymous. Yet because he relishes abrupt dynamic shifts and stylistic juxtapositions, his singing is full of surprises. A song that begins as a half-whisper can build to a fierce final shout, and jazz riffing can transform into flowery semioperatic flourishes. When Mr. Bennett chooses to zero in on the raw emotion of a ballad, however, the payoff is usually electrifying. During the Duke Ellington segment of his Carnegie Hall concert on Wednesday evening in the Verizon Music Festival, Mr. Bennett introduced ''Mood Indigo'' as his favorite Ellington song and bit into it with a keening vengeance. Pitching it near the top of his upper register, he turned it into a sustained cry of anguish that culminated in a rending melismatic descent on the final word: ''die.''

headline: A Modern Musician Plays the Host While Playing the Piano
summary: The young pianist Vijay Iyer isn't known for making superfriendly tonal harmony and swing rhythm; in his own quartet as well as in his cooperative trio, Fieldwork, there is plenty to hang on to in the way of rhythms and compositional structure, but the music isn't especially cozy. Still, during his solo piano set on Thursday night at the Jazz Standard -- part of a five-day series within the Verizon Music Festival, which is presenting a fine array of solo jazz pianists -- he played short pieces, paused to introduce new songs, welcomed the audience a few times and played host. This is what young jazz musicians do these days: it is an effect of having heard all your life the two contradictory, mindless pseudo-truisms that jazz is America's great music of the people and that it can be understood only by a narrow, smug elite. In fact, jazz is a viable art, and much remains to be said in it. But if your presentations are too obfuscatory, nobody is going to listen, and living in New York is too expensive to pretend otherwise.

headline: Supreme Court Seems Skeptical Of F.C.C. Position on Next Wave
summary: The Supreme Court gave a skeptical hearing today to the Federal Communications Commission's contention that it acted within its rights in 1998 when it confiscated more than 200 valuable wireless communications licenses from NextWave Telecom, which had won them at auction but fell behind in its payments and filed for bankruptcy protection. Under federal bankruptcy law, which is aimed at giving troubled companies a chance to reorganize and return to financial health, the government may not revoke a license ''solely because'' the holder has sought protection from its creditors. The federal appeals court here ruled last year that the F.C.C. violated this law by seizing the licenses for which NextWave had promised to pay more than $4 billion. Catching the telecommunications roller coaster at a high point, the commission then reauctioned the licenses to Verizon Wireless and other major companies for $16 billion. But the licenses have never been released because of the legal battle. A victory for NextWave would allow the company to use the licenses to finish building its wireless network or sell them to another company.

headline: A Live Ballgame Unfolds On a Cellphone Screen
summary: Awaiting applications for the so-called 3G (for third-generation) wireless protocol is a bit like wondering when electric cars will take over the nationrsquos highways. That technology, which will harness enough bandwidth to allow the transmission of streaming video and audio at rates of 2 megabits per second and higher, has yet to reach the mainstream consumer. But a team of companies is delivering graphics-rich content on wireless devices without the 3G bandwidth: Verizon and FoxSports.com have joined with ActiveSky to present live sports events and sports news to Internet-enabled cellphones for a monthly fee. ActiveSky, based in San Mateo, Calif., has created multiscene presentations that integrate visual action, sound, text and low-tech graphics in a facsimile of a live sports broadcast, as well as schedules, scores and standings. The service, available to Verizon Get It Now customers for $3.99 a month, provides baseball-game broadcasts in which tiny icons move around a color diamond while a box score and running text provide real-time updates on the game. For football games, a time clock and a tiny gridiron track the action.

headline: Footlights
summary: Historic Occasion With two-thirds of its soldiers dead, the First Minnesota Volunteer Infantry Regiment's 324 survivors stood ready beside 35,000 Pennsylvanians on the second day of the Battle of Gettysburg. In the first 15 minutes most of that unit's remaining men died. Yet the Minnesotans held the Union line, even charged Confederate positions; and their courage prevented a quick defeat. At battle's end, 40 to 80 survived. To commemorate the 140th anniversary of Gettysburg and the enduring bond between Minnesota and Pennsylvania, the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Minnesota Orchestra commissioned a Philadelphia-area composer, Amy Scurria (above), and a Minnesota composer, Steve Heitzeg, to collaborate on a composition. Their 18-minute work in three movements, ''We Are Met at Gettysburg,'' will have its world premiere at 11:30 a.m. on Saturday at a Philadelphia Orchestra Family Concert led by Giancarlo Guerrero in Verizon Hall at the Kimmel Center in Philadelphia.

headline: NextWave Victory May Not Prove Too Lucrative

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Verizon Asks Judge To Stay Court Order
summary: Verizon Communications asked a federal judge yesterday to stay his court order requiring the company to disclose the identity of an Internet subscriber to the Recording Industry Association of America. Verizon is appealing the case, which will determine whether copyright holders can use a shortcut subpoena process to gain access to personal information about Internet subscribers they suspect of illegally copying material online. The company said yesterday that it was asking Judge John Bates to block his order in Federal District Court in Washington until the United States Court of Appeals could review the case. The company argues that the recording industry's view of its rights under copyright law is incorrect and unconstitutional because it would violate the privacy of its subscribers. The recording industry association said it would oppose Verizon's effort to block the order. Amy Harmon (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Wireless To Offer Walkie-Talkie Service
summary: Verizon Wireless Inc., the biggest United States mobile phone company by subscribers, plans a walkie-talkie service this year that will let customers talk at the push of a button, a feature now sold only by Nextel Communications Inc. ''You will see us introduce a push-to-talk product well before the end of the year,'' the company's chief executive, Dennis Strigl, said yesterday at an investor conference in New York. Verizon Wireless joins rivals like Alltel in trying to match the walkie-talkie technology that has made Nextel unique in the mobile phone industry. Investors and analysts have said the popularity of that product among business customers helped Nextel increase sales and add subscribers at a faster pace than competitors last year. Shares of Nextel, the fifth-largest United States mobile phone company by customers, fell 45 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $12.31. Nextel phones include a technology developed by Motorola, the big maker of mobile phones, that lets customers talk to another person or a group of users by pushing a button, rather than dialing a number. Verizon Wireless does not trade publicly. The company is a joint venture of Verizon Communications Inc., the largest United States local phone company, and the Vodafone Group of Britain, the world's biggest mobile phone company.

summary: The BellSouth Corporation, the large local telephone company, and EarthLink Inc. expanded an agreement yesterday to sell high-speed Internet access over BellSouth's network in nine Southeastern states. headline: TV Viewers Are Riveted, And Overwhelmed, Too

headline: Making the Number Mobile, Too
summary: Standing on a Midtown Manhattan sidewalk, Martin Cooper, a Motorola engineer, made what is believed to have been the first cellular phone call ever 30 years ago this month. Using the bulky contraption he'd built himself, he dialed his competitors at Bell Labs, just to let them know he'd beaten them to the punch. We've come a long way since Mr. Cooper's first call, though not quite as far as we need to go before wireless phones fulfill their ultimate promise. High on the list of shortcomings is the fact that customers can't keep their number if they change service providers. If Verizon Wireless or Cingular had been around 30 years ago to sell Mr. Cooper a service plan, he would have had to stick with the company all these years, unless he'd been willing to surrender his number. This lack of number ''portability'' is an oddly paralyzing feature for a product that is all about promising hypermobility.

Now the Town of Riverhead, which owns the building and has offices there, is demanding $129,600 in back utility expenses. ''There have been on-going discussions periodically on how to resolve this matter,'' said Dawn C. Thomas, the Riverhead town attorney. headline: Cellphones Ring Out With the Help of a Steeple
summary: IN June 1973, lightning struck the steeple of the United Methodist Church in the small coastal town of Ipswich, Mass. The steeple, a prominent landmark since 1860 that appears on the town's seal, was badly damaged and had to be removed. The church lacked the money for a replacement, estimated to cost more than $100,000. But the church's luck changed in 1996, with the proposal of an unusual way to pay for a new steeple. Bell Atlantic (now part of Verizon) was searching for a site for a cellular phone transmission tower in Ipswich but had been blocked from building one by the town zoning board.

headline: In the Region/Westchester; Fuji Photo Moves Its Base to Valhalla From Elmsford
summary: IN the largest commercial leasing deal in Westchester in two years, Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. moved its United States headquarters last week, along with 330 employees, from cramped quarters in Elmsford to 164,000 square feet in an office park here. The United States marketing unit of the Tokyo-based Fuji Photo Film Company has signed a 10-year lease and spent about $10 million to refurbish the space at the Summit at Valhalla, a 102-acre office park built by Cappelli Enterprises in 1990 and acquired by Reckson Associates in 1998. Other tenants at the corporate park include Verizon, PepsiCo and Nortel.

headline: Investing; Ferreting Out the Fittest in Cable
summary: SHARES of cable companies have generally performed well this year, but when Verizon Communications, the telecommunications company, announced this month that it was cutting the rates that consumers pay for high-speed Internet access, shares of a broad range of the companies fell. High-speed Internet access has been the fastest-growing sector for most cable companies. The Verizon announcement, on May 2, suggested a possible price war between cable and telecommunications companies, a prospect that troubles many investors. From that day until last Tuesday, most major cable stocks, including those of the Comcast Corporation, Cox Communications, Cablevision Systems and Mediacom Communications, dropped by about 5 percent or more; most have recovered partially since then.

headline: Phone Companies See Their Future In Flat-Rate Plans Of Many Services
summary: Fifteen years ago, Arthur C. Clarke in the science-fiction novel ''2061: Odyssey Three'' predicted a future as follows: ''With the historic abolition of long-distance charges on 31 December 2000, every telephone call became a local one, and the human race greeted the new millennium by transforming itself into one huge, gossiping family.'' That future may be at hand, only a few years behind schedule, as a result of the telephone industry's declining economic fortunes, increasing competition and recent technological advances. Starting with MCI, which introduced its Neighborhood plan in April 2002, most leading phone companies -- AT&T, BellSouth, Qwest Communications, SBC Communications and Verizon -- have rolled out programs that allow customers in some states to make unlimited local and national calls for one flat monthly price.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T To Sell Services From Former Division
summary: AT&T will start selling a package of services that includes mobile calling from AT&T Wireless Services, a company it spun off in 2001. Terms were not disclosed. The service package will be tested in some markets in the next few months and be offered nationwide by year's end, a spokesman, Gary Morgenstern, said. AT&T also sells Internet access and local calling to some of its 43 million residential customers. AT&T wants to sell partners' products to win and keep customers, after abandoning a plan to sell phone, wireless and cable service from under the same roof in 2000. Local carriers like Verizon Communications have added long distance to their offerings, and analysts say subscribers with multiple calling services on one bill are less likely to switch carriers. Shares of AT&T fell 34 cents, to $18.91.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Delinquent Telecom Debt
summary: One of Mexico's largest wireless telephone companies, Grupo Iusacell, missed a $25 million payment on its $350 million 2006 bond and promised to come up with a debt restructuring plan within the 30-day grace period. The operator, which is jointly owned by Verizon Comunications and the Vodafone Group, has about $815 million in total debt. The company has struggled for several years behind Mexico's dominant wireless carrier, América Móvil, and faces well-financed competition from Telefónica Móviles of Spain, which is moving aggressively into the Mexican market this year. Some market analysts speculate that if Iusacell can work out a favorable restructuring plan with creditors, then Verizon may be willing to put new capital into the company. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

headline: In a Reversal, Verizon Backs Rule to Keep Cell Numbers
summary: Verizon Wireless said yesterday that it would drop its opposition to a government plan to allow callers to keep their wireless phone numbers when they switch carriers. The about-face by Verizon Wireless, the nation's largest mobile phone company, probably means that some other mobile phone operators will have little choice but to yield to the arrangement. Verizon, which has led a protracted, industrywide effort to prevent the Federal Communications Commission from requiring that cellphone numbers be portable from provider to provider, said it now supported F.C.C. rules scheduled to take effect on Nov. 24 and would end its legal and legislative campaign against them.

headline: Company Tries to Catch Up On Repairs on Long Island
summary: With Verizon workers poised to go on strike this weekend, about 2,400 orders for phone-line installations on Long Island have gone unfilled as workers scramble to respond to a glut of repair orders, according to union leaders. Last Friday, Verizon declared a state of emergency on Long Island, which allows the company to demand extra overtime from its workers. Since then, workers have been responding only to repair calls and emergency phone-line installations, said Bob Morrow, vice president for Communications Workers of America Local 1108 in Suffolk County.

headline: TELLABS TO CLOSE PLANT AND LAY OFF 325 WORKERS
summary: Tellabs Inc. said yesterday that it would close a plant in Bolingbrook, Ill., and send the manufacturing work to the Sanmina-SCI Corporation, eliminating 325 jobs. The shift will cost Tellabs $90 million to $110 million in the third quarter. Tellabs, a maker of fiber optic network equipment, has been struggling as customers including Verizon Communications Inc. have cut spending on networks. Sanmina-SCI, based in San Jose, Calif., makes electronic products like printers and computers. Tellabs has been a Sanmina-SCI customer for more than 10 years. Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Wireless Access At F.C.C.
summary: The Federal Communications Commission is providing free wireless Internet access to visitors at its Washington headquarters. ''When you come to the F.C.C., leave the cords at home,'' said Michael K. Powell, chairman of the commission. ''We're embracing the power of 'Wi-Fi' and the freedom and convenience of wireless Internet access it gives to consumers.'' Last year, Mr. Powell told his staff to take steps to make the F.C.C. one of the first federal agencies to provide public Internet access through the Wi-Fi radio signal technology. Visitors who bring their own hardware will be able to use the service at the agency's building and in its courtyard. In May, Verizon announced that it would provide Wi-Fi access from phone booths around Manhattan. Wireless access is also available in some hotels, airports, convention centers, restaurants and other locations.

summary: Raising the stakes in the protracted contract negotiations between Verizon and its unions, labor officials planned to announce a campaign today to collect the names of people who would be willing to switch their service to AT&T, a competing provider of local, long-distance and wireless phone services. headline: Verizon's Pact Seen as Critical To Its Industry
summary: Verizon's unions were quite happy with the settlement they reached Thursday night with the company, but some analysts contend that the deal could make it harder for the nation's large telephone service providers to face increasing threats to their business from the cable industry and a variety of upstarts. The settlement comes as companies in the traditional local telephone industry, like Verizon, SBC Communications and Bell South, are moving from the effective monopoly control over direct access to consumers and business they long enjoyed to a much more challenging situation contending with powerful cable companies like Cox and Comcast that are offering rival data and voice services through their own pipes into homes and offices.

headline: Snap a Photo And Ship It, Without Hanging Up
summary: The digital cameras on telephones are not just point-and-shoot numbers these days, and the VX6000 from LG is a case in point: it comes with zoom control and three different picture resolutions. Chatty shutterbugs can also add color and special effects to their photos and then e-mail them by way of a picture-messaging service recently started by Verizon Wireless. In addition to its 1x, 2x and 4x zoom and picture resolutions of 160 by 120 pixels, 320 by 240 pixels and 640 by 480 pixels, the LG VX6000 can take up to five photos in a row without interruption. Other features on the phone include a color screen, Web browsing and e-mail software, a built-in personal organizer and as much as three and a half hours of talk time on a battery charge. The VX6000 normally sells for $200, but Verizon Wireless is offering a $50 mail-in rebate until Oct. 13.

headline: ARTS BRIEFING
summary: HIGHLIGHTS PHILADELPHIA: A GIFT TO MUSIC A $50 million gift to the Philadelphia Orchestra, the largest in its history, was announced yesterday on the eve of the opening of the orchestra's 104th season and its first under its new music director, Christoph Eschenbach, left. The gift, from the Annenberg Foundation, came as the orchestra opened the public phase of a five-year, $125 million endowment campaign. Including the Annenberg gift, the orchestra said that commitments to the drive, called ''A Sound, a City, a Civilization'' and intended to assure the future of the orchestra, now total more than $75 million. At 8:30 p.m. tomorrow in Verizon Hall at the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia, Mr. Eschenbach, succeeding Wolfgang Sawallisch and becoming the orchestra's seventh music director, will lead the Philadelphians and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma in works by Berlioz, Dvorak and Brahms.

headline: After Blackout, a Call for a 911 Overhaul
summary: The Bloomberg administration released a report yesterday recommending an overhaul of the 911 emergency phone system to strengthen its technology and streamline the way calls are handled. In the report, ordered by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to examine how the city operated and responded to the Aug. 14 power failure, officials noted that the 911 system failed in several ways. The high volume of calls overloaded the system at points, so some calls could not get through. Then backup generators at some Verizon offices did not work, city officials said, knocking out the Fire Department's and Emergency Medical Service's 911 dispatching three times for periods of between 7 and 14 minutes.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon And WorldCom Settle Connection Dispute
summary: Verizon Communications agreed yesterday to pay WorldCom $169 million to settle a dispute over network-connection fees. Since 1997, the companies have been arguing over whether their interconnection agreement requires Verizon to pay fees to WorldCom for calls made by Verizon customers to Internet service providers that are customers of WorldCom. As part of the settlement, Verizon also agreed to interconnection rates intended to avoid future litigation or arbitration. ''Approval of the settlement agreement will result in the adoption of amendments to the interconnection agreements that will resolve the uncertainties by establishing a rate regime applicable for a period of three years,'' WorldCom said in a motion filed Friday in Bankruptcy Court in New York. A hearing has been scheduled for Monday, during which Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez, who is presiding over the WorldCom bankruptcy, will hear arguments on whether to approve the settlement. Calls and pages to a WorldCom representative were not immediately answered.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon-Worldcom Settlement Is Approved
summary: WorldCom received court approval of a $169 million payment from Verizon Communications to settle a dispute over network-access fees. The settlement, approved yesterday by Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, ends a six-year-old dispute over whether Verizon must pay when its customers make calls to Internet access providers that use WorldCom's phone lines. Verizon, the nation's largest local-telephone company, also agreed to pay revised interconnection rates to avoid future legal problems. The dispute ''is possibly the largest collective piece of litigation'' at WorldCom and ''resolving it is very key in all of the processes,'' Alfredo Perez, WorldCom's bankruptcy lawyer, told Judge Gonzalez. In July 2002 WorldCom filed the biggest bankruptcy case in United States history in terms of declared asset value. The company, based in Ashburn, Va., expects to complete its reorganization and come out of bankruptcy early next year as MCI, the name of its best-known unit. Verizon shares rose 41 cents, to $34.32.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Shares Surge On Verizon Venture
summary: Shares of the Nortel Networks Corporation, North America's largest maker of telephone equipment, rose 19 percent yesterday after Verizon Communications selected Nortel to provide equipment for Internet-based phone calls. The companies agreed to initial terms of a contract and expect to sign a five-year agreement on converting Verizon's network with new packet switches and other Web-calling gear in the next few months, they said. A Verizon spokesman, Mark Marchand, would not say how much the contract was worth. Nortel expects to report a profit for 2003 after net losses of more than $35 billion in the preceding five years. Nortel is winning orders as carriers upgrade networks with packet-switching technology, which compresses voice and data traffic so it can be sent together over high-speed lines. Shares of Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, rose 92 cents, to $5.68. The shares are down from a high of $89 in July 2000. Verizon shares rose 8 cents, to $36.56.
