headline: VERIZON WIRELESS LOOKS OUTSIDE INTERPUBLIC GROUP
summary: In a potential blow to the Interpublic Group of Companies, Verizon Wireless, one of Interpublic's largest clients, said yesterday that it would expand a search for creative ideas beyond two Interpublic agencies that have been reviewed since October: Lowe & Partners Worldwide, the incumbent, and McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising. Verizon Wireless, a joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone that spends more than $700 million a year on marketing, is seeking new ways to present in its ads the character who asks ''Can you hear me now?'' Because ''we're not completely satisfied with what we saw, we're going to open it up to other agencies,'' said Brenda Raney, a spokeswoman at Verizon Wireless in Bedminster, N.J.. A spokesman at Interpublic in New York, Philippe Krakowsky, said, ''Our work has helped build one of America's most powerful brands, and we look forward to defending the business.'' Stuart Elliott (NYT)

headline: Verizon Wireless Outpaces Rivals in New Subscribers

That total is far below analysts' expectations, which had ranged up to almost nine million.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Study Shows One In Four Subway Phones Flawed
summary: About one in four pay telephones in the New York City subway and commuter rail system do not work properly, according to a survey released yesterday by the Straphangers Campaign, a passenger advocacy group. Volunteers and staff members of the group spent four months surveying 100 stations picked at random from the 712 stations in the system. About 27 percent of subway pay phones surveyed did not work, compared with 17 percent of Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad pay phones, the survey said. The most common problems were no dial tone on the phone (38 percent); failure to return a coin (24 percent); coin not registering (13 percent); coin slot blocked (11 percent); inability to connect a call (10 percent); and flawed handset (5 percent). A Verizon spokesman, Daniel Diaz Zapata, said that the problems stemmed from vandalism and the difficulty of tracking the phones' condition. He urged riders to dial *55 from a working phone to report a problem. Michael Luo (NYT)

headline: Used Cellphones Find a Market Among Bare-Bones Users
summary: EVEN as the latest cellphone models arrive in showcases, a new breed of shopper is scouring online ads and dark corners of stores for a bargain phone with a little mileage on it. As cellphones become routine for even the cash-strapped and the very young, more Americans are willing to pay for handsets previously used by other hands. Josh Cain, 16, of Los Angeles spent $29.99 last month for a refurbished Siemens C56 offered by AT&T Wireless at its Web site (www.attws.com) as part of its pay-as-you-go GoPhone plan. A computer-science major at California State University, Los Angeles -- he entered at age 13 -- Josh already had a cellphone included in his father's Verizon Wireless account. But the refurbished handset was ''a cheap option to try out G.S.M.,'' he said, referring to the Global System for Mobile Communications, a standard used by AT&T Wireless, T-Mobile, Cingular and many European carriers.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Rivals Offered Higher Rate-Leasing Plans
summary: Verizon Communications, the telecommunications giant based in New York, introduced a contractual framework yesterday for leasing its lines to competing telephone companies. Verizon said that it would lease its lines in customized three-year deals to competitors. Verizon, which operates in 30 states, said the price would vary by state but would typically range from $20 to $24 per telephone line a month, with the cost rising each subsequent year. The offer from Verizon follows similar proposals by other regional telephone giants, like SBC and BellSouth. Generally, the offers come after a recent appeals court decision that threw out federal rules forcing the dominant local phone companies, like Verizon, to lease their networks to competitors at low rates set by state regulators. Matt Richtel (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Less Cellphone Number Switching Than Expected
summary: The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that rules allowing consumers to keep cellphone numbers when switching carriers had a weaker impact on the industry than expected. But the new rule, which became effective last November, has increased competition among carriers. John B. Muleta, chief of the commission's Wireless Telecommunications Bureau, said more than two million numbers had been transferred since last November, far fewer than the 12 million some industry analysts had predicted. The rule has caused a shift in market share among carriers, Mr. Muleta said, without providing specifics. Company reports show AT&T Wireless had the most defections by customers in the first quarter, while Verizon Wireless had the fewest. Number portability has only been available in the 100 largest markets since November. On May 24, number portability will become available in the rest of the country. Ken Belson (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Telephone Plan Opposed
summary: Nine months of talks among the nation's major telecommunications companies aimed at ending costly fees for connecting each other's phone calls faltered yesterday when Verizon Communications and BellSouth withheld support for a final proposal. A group of 19 telephone service providers had hoped to present federal regulators with a plan that would eliminate the fees the companies pay each other but raise consumers' line charges. Company officials worry that consumers would see the jump in line charges and not realize that they are paying less for long-distance and local calls. They are also concerned that the plan would be impossible to enact when voters are already upset about the rising cost of consumer goods.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: NextWave Settlement Approved
summary: NextWave Telecom has won approval of a settlement with federal regulators that resolves a dispute over a $4.3 billion debt for airwave licenses purchased at government auctions. NextWave agreed last month to return most of its spectrum licenses to the Federal Communications Commission and either give back other airwave rights or pay $386 million out of proceeds from their sale. The accord, approved by Judge Adlai S. Hardin Jr. of Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains, gives mobile carriers like Verizon Wireless another opportunity to buy the licenses. ''I have been before you a lot of times in the past six years and there have been a lot of twists and turns in this case,'' a NextWave lawyer, Deborah Schrier-Rape, told Judge Hardin. ''We are here to end the problem that has governed NextWave for the past six years.'' The legal battle between NextWave and the commission culminated in a United States Supreme Court decision last year that allowed NextWave to keep the spectrum that the government reclaimed in 2000. NextWave owed the commission $4.3 billion out of $4.8 billion for the licenses won in auctions in 1996 and 1997 and the debt remained an obstacle to its successful reorganization. The company expects to submit a reorganization plan by July, said Michael Wack, a NextWave lawyer and spokesman.

Vodafone, the world's largest cellphone provider, has that option. As part of its deal with Verizon Communications, which owns the other 55 percent of Verizon Wireless, Vodafone can demand up to $20 billion for its stake in the venture, to be paid in two equal payments. headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cablevision Offers $90 Monthly Package
summary: The Cablevision Systems Corporation, the largest cable-television operator in the New York area, said yesterday that it had begun offering a $90-a-month package of TV, telephone and Web-access service to lure customers from satellite and telephone competitors. The subscription rate, valid for the first year, costs $50 a month less than the three services, bought separately, would cost at regular prices. Customers will receive a basic package of more than 140 TV networks including CBS, Nickelodeon and CNN, as well as digital phone service and high-speed Web access, Cablevision said. Cable television companies are adding phone service and bundling offerings to increase sales and reduce customer defections. Cablevision's competitors, including the DirecTV Group, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, and local phone companies like Verizon Communications, are jointly selling packages of services to customers. Cablevision's phone service, which uses so-called voice-over-Internet protocol technology to carry the calls over the cable systems, had 71,000 customers as of March 31. Shares of Cablevision fell 78 cents, to $21.22.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 2 Wireless Carriers Plan New Data Networks
summary: Two major wireless carriers announced plans yesterday to introduce high-speed data networks to keep up with Verizon Wireless and other rivals. Sprint said it planned to spend $1 billion in the next two years to upgrade the speed of its network. The company will spend most of that money in 2005 as it installs EV-DO, or evolution data optimized, service. EV-DO technology allows faster speeds for sending data to and from cellphones. Verizon Wireless, the country's biggest cellphone provider, is already upgrading its network using EV-DO technology. Separately, Cingular Wireless said it would accept bids from telecommunications equipment makers for a high-speed data network using U.M.T.S., or Universal Mobile Telecommunications System, technology. EV-DO and U.M.T.S. let cellphone users download video, music, e-mail and other data at speeds 40 times or more faster than current cellphone connections. Ken Belson (NYT)

headline: The Voice Of the Worker
summary: In most industries, the sixth-largest player would be considered an also-ran. In the cellphone world, the sixth-largest carrier, Nextel Communications, is the one to watch. Nextel's rapidly improving business has defied skeptics, who have long seen the company as a scrappy, but distant, contender. Created in 1987 when its predecessor, Fleet Call, started buying spectrum licenses used by radio dispatchers, the company teetered financially for years. It has few ties to telephone giants like Verizon and AT&T. And its offbeat ''Push To Talk'' service, which lets cellphones double as walkie-talkies, was considered too cute to be a threat in the turbulent mobile phone market.

headline: The Week Ahead
summary: SMALL CHANGE -- Some consumers will receive a rare commodity in their phone bills: an honest to goodness rate rollback, albeit one measured in dimes. Beginning with its billing cycle next week, Verizon Wireless will eliminate a 40-cent monthly fee to cover the costs associated with a rule, enacted a year ago, allowing customers to keep their phone numbers when switching service providers. Responding in part to Sprint, which cut a similar fee to 25 cents from 40 cents, Verizon, the nation's second-largest mobile phone carrier, will forgo $15 million a month. Dimes add up when you have more than 40 million customers. GOING NUCLEAR -- The future, it appears, is going to be a tough place to get to. A consortium of countries, including members of the European Union, along with South Korea, Japan, China, the United States and Russia, has been working on a futuristic fusion reactor that will be three decades and about $10 billion in the making. But creating a clean and everlasting source of energy may be simple compared to figuring out where to build the reactor. Beginning Thursday, the European Union members will meet to discuss how to convince the other partners that France should be the host country, as Russia and China are reported to favor.

headline: In U.S. Market, Cellphone Users Are Often All Talk
summary: One of the most popular new cellphones this holiday season is the Razr, an ultrathin model that stresses style over services. That is good news for Motorola, which makes the Razr, but bad news for wireless carriers that are spending billions of dollars to build high-speed networks in the hopes that their customers will do more than just talk. Carriers like Cingular Wireless and Verizon Wireless are hoping that faster speeds will entice customers to use more data services -- trading photos, downloading songs and surfing the Internet on their handsets. Such services can add more than $10 a month to subscribers' bills and help defray the cost of the extra voice minutes that carriers are offering customers to keep them from jumping to competitors.

headline: Latest Merger Would Recast Cellular's Face Once Again
summary: For most of its two decades on the American landscape, the cellphone industry has been known for its freewheeling upstarts and aggressive competition. Yet in just a few years, a wave of mergers has left the industry dominated by a handful of giant companies, with smaller contenders having to carve out niche markets to survive. The industry was further recast yesterday when Sprint and Nextel Communications -- two of the more distinctive and entrepreneurial mobile phone companies -- formally announced a merger that will create a formidable No.3 carrier. The new company, to be called Sprint Nextel, will join Cingular Wireless, which has 46 million subscribers, and Verizon Wireless, with 42 million, in an elite trio that will control three-quarters of the market.

headline: Want to Retire Early? Well, It May Take Some Work
summary: LYDIA POSNER was not considering retirement last year when Verizon offered her a buyout package. ''I always felt like I would work forever, so this was a very emotional decision for me,'' said Mrs. Posner, who was employed as a technical writer. ''I drove my husband and children crazy for six weeks talking about it, until my kids finally said, 'Mom, you worked for 31 years, you deserve this.''' Mrs. Posner was 56 when she retired in 2003. She is among the thousands of employees who have decided to call it quits in recent years after being offered buyout packages, which many companies have been turning to as an alternative to involuntary layoffs during cost cutting. Many other workers are quitting their jobs years before they qualify for Social Security payments, without the incentive of a buyout.

headline: Why MCI Is Turning Up Its Nose at $1.3 Billion
summary: INVESTORS might be forgiven if they are perplexed by MCI's decision last week to accept a $7.6 billion takeover bid from Verizon Communications instead of an offer from Qwest Communications that was worth nearly 20 percent more. Money is money, after all, and shareholders -- who own the company -- deserve the most for their stock. But the decision by MCI's board is about more than the $1.3 billion left on the table. In considering offers during a two-month bidding war, the board decided that the current dollar value of the deals was just one consideration. The directors also tried to determine what the deals would be worth a year from now, when regulators are likely to sign off. Ultimately, the board concluded that Verizon's mix of stock and cash would be worth more than Qwest's.

headline: Wireless Net Connections For the Roaming Laptop
summary: The trouble with wireless local area networks (LAN's) is that they're local, generally limiting your laptop's access to the bounds of your home or office. Wi-Fi access in airport lounges, coffeehouses and elsewhere can be expensive, and access points are not always nearby. As an alternative, you can use wireless data networks offered by cellular providers, but they have been slow -- only two to three times as fast as dial-up modems. Now broadband service (about five to nine times as fast as dial-up, with high-speed downloads available in bursts) is available from Verizon Wireless for $79.99 a month.

headline: N.A.A.C.P. Chooses Retired Executive As New Leader
summary: For the first time in decades, the N.A.A.C.P. is not tapping a politician or a minister, but instead a retired business executive to lead the nation's largest civil rights organization. Bruce S. Gordon, 59, a former executive at Verizon Communications Inc., is to succeed Kweisi Mfume as president and chief executive. Mr. Mfume left the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in December and is running for the United States Senate in Maryland.

headline: Good Vibrations: Video Games On a Cellphone, With Feedback
summary: Cellphone vibrations were devised as a silent way to alert you to an incoming call. The SCH-N330 from Samsung takes the tremble another step, vibrating with the bumps of the road in a racing game and pulsating with the melody of a ring tone. The phone, available from Verizon for $69.99 with a two-year contract, uses a VibeTonz System developed by Immersion, the company whose force-feedback technology is used to make game controllers and joysticks shake and shudder. In the Highway Racer game, the phone rumbles steadily as you move down the road, but the feel of the vibration changes if you roll onto dirt or grass. In the Shot Mobile golf game, you feel the impact of the club hitting the ball.

headline: Former Executive Chosen to Lead N.A.A.C.P.
summary: The N.A.A.C.P., departing from a custom of looking to political or religious figures to lead the organization, named a former business executive, Bruce S. Gordon, as its president and chief executive on Saturday. Meeting in private, about 60 members of the organization's board voted unanimously to choose Mr. Gordon, 59, who retired in 2003 as president of the retail markets group for Verizon Communications. Mr. Gordon will now negotiate a contract with the N.A.A.C.P.'s executive committee; if they reach a deal, the board will formally vote on Mr. Gordon's appointment at its convention next month in Milwaukee.

headline: Sorry, Can't Talk Now. I'm Downloading.
summary: Now that cellphones let you take pictures, play games and browse the Web, making a voice call may be the least exciting thing you can do with them. The new LG VX8100 handset, which works with Verizon Wireless service, livens things up even more by adding a video camera, an MP3 player, stereo speakers and high-speed Internet connectivity. The LG VX8100 uses Verizon's high-speed evolution-data optimized network, available in many cities, to receive news and sports video clips. The phone takes 1.3-megapixel still photos and has a video camera that can send clips to other video-enabled phones or e-mail addresses.

headline: MCI Posts Profitable Quarter, First Since End of Bankruptcy
summary: MCI Inc., the long-distance carrier that has agreed to be sold to Verizon Communications, said yesterday that it earned $64 million, or 19 cents a share, in the second quarter, beating Wall Street's expectations. It was MCI's first profitable quarter since emerging from bankruptcy last year. The company, based in Ashburn, Va., lost $71 million, or 22 cents a share, in the quarter last year.

headline: MCI's Unpaid Bills May Trim Its Selling Price to Verizon
summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it could reduce its price for MCI by as much as $60.8 million, or 21 cents a share, if the company's tax and bankruptcy liabilities exceeded forecasts. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Verizon said that if MCI spent more than $1.78 billion to settle bankruptcy claims and tax liabilities, Verizon could reduce its purchase price.

headline: Spare Times
summary: Attractions Museums and Sites MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, East Village. This preserved late-Federal brick house with a Greek Revival interior, once owned by Seabury Tredwell, a wealthy hardware dealer, was built in 1832. Through Oct. 3, ''Understanding Architectural Moldings,'' an exhibition that includes artifacts from Federal, Greek Revival and Italianate town houses. Self-guided tours are available on weekdays, guided tours on Saturdays and Sundays. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; students and 62+, $5; members and children under 12, free. Information: (212)777-1089. MUSEUM OF CHINESE IN THE AMERICAS, 70 Mulberry Street, Chinatown. Through Dec. 31, ''Archivist of the 'Yellow Peril': Yoshio Kishi Collecting for a New America,'' an exhibition of books, movie posters, cartoons and other items that document Asian stereotypes. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Fridays, noon to 7 p.m. Admission: $3; 62+ and students, $1; 12 and under and museum members, free; admission is free for everyone on Fridays. Information: (212)619-4785; www.moca-nyc.org. MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Through Oct. 2, ''Peter Sellers: Does That Include Television?,'' excerpts from his appearances on American and British television. Through Sunday, ''TV Goes Hollywood,'' with episodes from ''The Honeymooners.'' Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 62+, $8; children under 14, $5. Information: (212)621-6800. NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street, Lincoln Center Plaza. Through Oct. 15, ''A Community of Artists: 50 Years of the Public Theater,'' with photographs, programs, costumes and other items. Through tomorrow, ''America's Irreplaceable Dance Treasures: The First 100,'' coordinated by the Dance Heritage Coalition. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, noon to 8 p.m. Free. Information: (212)642-0142. NEW YORK TRANSIT MUSEUM, Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn Heights. Through Dec. 4, ''Subway People: Alone in the Crowd,'' an exhibition of photographs by David Perlmutter. Sunday at noon, ''Nostalgia Train Ride: The Rockaways on the IND,'' a daylong excursion from Manhattan to Queens aboard vintage subway cars, beginning and ending in Manhattan at Columbus Circle and 59th Street; the trip includes a two-hour stop for a National Park Service nature program at Jacob Riis Park. Admission, $25; 3 to 17, $10; reservations, (718)694-1867. Gardens WAVE HILL, Independence Avenue and West 249th Street, Riverdale, the Bronx. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''The Nightshade Family: Passion or Poison?,'' a walk to identify the edible and toxic varieties of this plant. Tomorrow and Sunday at 1 p.m., ''Shades of Summer,'' how to make multicolored sunglasses for viewing gardens. Sunday at 1 p.m., ''Tinctures and Salves,'' a workshop in making herbal salves. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.. Admission: $4; students and 65+, $2; under 6, free; Tuesdays, free admission; Saturdays, free 9 a.m. to noon. Information: (718)549-3200. STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. Sunday at 1 p.m., a lecture on feng shui on the lawn of the Carl Grillo Glass House. Open Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (Fridays to 8 p.m.). The one-acre New York Chinese Scholars' Garden and the Secret Garden are open Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Scholars' Garden admission: $5; 62+ and children under 12, $4; Secret Garden, $2; children, $1; adults with a child, free. Grounds hours: daily, dawn to dusk; free admission. Information: (718)273-8200. Walking Tours New York City SPANISH HARLEM SALSA TOUR Includes social clubs, botanicas and homes of famous salsa musicians. Saturdays and Sundays at noon. Thursdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m., tours sometimes include live performances. Fee: $25. Information: www.salsasight.com. Sponsored by the Lubano Corporation. Meeting place and reservations: (212)253-8702. THE CATHEDRAL CHURCH OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights. Tomorrow at 12:45 p.m., ''Looking Upward: An Architectural Tour,'' a look at the angels, beasts and prophets that adorn the cathedral's structures. Fee: $10; children, $8. Information: (212)932-7347. HISTORIC BROADWAY THEATER DISTRICT TOUR, covering 10 blocks of historic sites in the theater district. Saturdays and Sundays at 10 a.m. Fee: $10. Sponsored by New York Curmudgeon Tours. Information and meeting place: (212)629-8813. OUTDOORS CLUB Sunday at 1 p.m., Fort Tryon Park to Van Cortlandt Park, a four-mile hike from Inwood to the Bronx, meeting outside the 190th Street and Washington Avenue subway stop on the A train. Fee: $3. Information: (212)533-9457. THE MUNICIPAL ART SOCIETY OF NEW YORK Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''Hudson River Vistas: Riverside Park and Riverside Drive'' visits the marina, public art and architecture along the riverfront, meeting on the northeast corner of Riverside Drive and 76th Street. Sunday at 11 a.m., ''Bay Ridge North'' looks at the varied housing found in the Brooklyn neighborhood, meeting outside the Bay Ridge subway stop on the R train, Fourth and Bay Ridge Avenues. Fee for each: $15; members, $12. Information: (212)935-3960. EIGHTH STREET AND ST. MARKS PLACE A look at the area's history and its famous cultural and political residents, meeting tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. on the northwest corner of Second Avenue and St. Marks Place, East Village. Free. Sponsored by the Village Alliance Business Improvement District. Information: (212)777-2173. BIG ONION WALKING TOURS Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Park Slope,'' Brooklyn, with stops at the Montauk Club and Litchfield Manor, meeting on the southeast corner of Plaza Street West and Flatbush Avenue. Fee: $15; 63+, $12; students, $10. Information: (212)439-1090. CENTURY WALKING TOURS Tomorrow at 11 a.m., the Madison Square section of Manhattan, meeting at the Admiral Farragut statue at the northern end of Madison Square Park, Fifth Avenue and 26th Street. Sunday at 11 a.m., ''Ayn Rand's Park Avenue,'' exploring sites related to Rand, the author of ''Atlas Shrugged'' and other novels, meeting at the Met Life Building, East 45th Street at Lexington Avenue. Fee for each: $15. Information: (917)607-9019. HISTORIC GOVERNORS ISLAND. Free 90-minute tours led by National Park Service rangers, Tuesdays through Fridays at 10 a.m. and 1 p.m. through Sept. 3. A ferry ride is required: tickets, $6; children 5 to 12, $3; under 5, free. Ferry tickets can be bought in advance or on the day of the tour; no reservations are taken. Tickets can be bought at two Lower Manhattan locations: the New York Water Taxi booth, Pier 11, Wall and South Streets; and the South Street Seaport Museum, Pier 16, Fulton and South Street. The ferry leaves from the Battery Maritime Building, Slip 7, 10 South Street; passengers should arrive 15 minutes before departure time. Information: (212)742-1969; www.nps.gov/gois; www.nywatertaxi.com. BROOKLYN CENTER FOR THE URBAN ENVIRONMENT Tomorrow at 11 a.m., Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, former farmland that is now a multicultural hub of residences, stores and cultural sites, meeting by the HSBC Bank, Hanson and Ashland Places. Fee: $11; members, $9; students, $8. Information: (718)788-8500, ext. 208. METRO TOUR SERVICE visits Brooklyn Heights, Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, today through Sunday at 2 p.m., and Downtown Brooklyn, with a stop for gospel music, on Sunday at 10 a.m. All meeting in front of the Marriott, Adams and Tillary Streets, Downtown Brooklyn. Fee: $25. Information: (718)789-0430. I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN TOURS Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Mansions, Millions and Magnificence,'' focusing on the architecture, history, landmarks and past residents of this Midtown stretch of Fifth Avenue and vicinity, meeting at the statue of General Sherman. Fee: $12. Information: (732)270-5559. CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY Free weekend tours of Central Park: tomorrow at 11 a.m., ''Hallett Nature Sanctuary,'' meeting at the Dairy Visitor Center, midpark at 65th Street. Sunday at 2 p.m., ''The Castle and Its Kingdom,'' focusing on Belvedere Castle, meeting at the Castle, midpark at 79th Street. Information: (212)360-2726. Events New York City SUMMER SEAPORT FESTIVAL, Water Street, from Fulton to Moore Streets, Lower Manhattan. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Downtown Republican Club. VILLAGE VISITING NEIGHBORS STREET FAIR, University Place, between Waverly Place and 14th Street, West Village. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. INDIA INDEPENDENCE DAY PARADE, Madison Avenue, from 41st to 27th Streets. Sunday at 1 p.m., followed by a festival on Madison Avenue, from 23rd to 26th Streets. ST. CECILE SCHOLARSHIP FUND STREET FAIR, Avenue of the Americas, from 14th to 23rd Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. LEXINGTON AVENUE SUMMERFEST, from 42nd to 57th Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the East 55th Street Synagogue. 'WOMEN HOOFERS FROM PHILA,' Cobi's Place, 158 West 48th Street, Manhattan. A screening of vintage films of black American dancers and a discussion with the dance historian Delilah Jackson. Tomorrow at 2:30 p.m. Admission: $5. Information: (516)922-2010. SUNNYSIDE FESTIVAL, Greenpoint Avenue, from 44th to 48th Streets, Sunnyside, Queens. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Sunnyside Chamber of Commerce. FORT GREENE PARK SUMMER LITERARY FESTIVAL, between DeKalb and Myrtle Avenues, Fort Greene, Brooklyn. With readings and music. Tomorrow at 4:30 p.m. Sponsored by the New York Writers Coalition. CONEY ISLAND MEMORY DAY, Astroland Park, Brooklyn. Visitors can record their memories of the amusement park tomorrow at 1 p.m. There will also be entertainment and a photography display. Sponsored by the Coney Island History Project. Information: (718)265-2100; www.coneyislandvoices.com. HARLEM WEEK Tomorrow, ''Uptown Saturday Night,'' with free entertainment from noon to 9 p.m. on stages at St. Nicholas Avenue and 135th Street; and a free children's festival with rides and performances from noon to 6 p.m. on 135th Street, between Malcolm X and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevards. Sunday, ''Harlem Day,'' with entertainment, a fashion show and other activities, from noon to 9 p.m. at St. Nicholas Avenue and 135th Street; and a health fair from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. at 135th Street, between Malcolm X and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevards. Information: (212)862-8477; www.HarlemDiscover.com. 'SNAUSAGES DOG DAY IN THE PARK,' Shea Stadium, picnic area entrance, Flushing, Queens. Baseball fans and their dogs can see the Mets play the Nationals in the picnic area of the stadium, tomorrow at 7:10 p.m.; check-in, 5:45 p.m. Tickets: $30 for two-legged fans, $5 a dog; proceeds from canine admissions benefit the North Shore Animal League. Information: (718)565-4348. TROPICAL MUSIC FESTIVAL, Orchard Beach, Section 9, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx. A free series of Latin music concerts continues Sunday, noon to 5 p.m., with performances by Santiago Cerón, Sonido Amante, Angelo y Su Conjunto Modelo and Alex Diaz y Sabor Latino. Part of Sundays at Orchard Beach. Sponsored by Heineken, Verizon and other corporations. Information: (718)885-2275. FLATBUSH AVENUE FESTIVAL, from Cortelyou Road to Parkside Avenue, Flatbush, Brooklyn. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. WASHINGTON AVENUE MERCHANTS STREET FAIR, from Eastern Parkway to St. Marks Avenue, Crown Heights, Brooklyn. Sunday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. 'A TRIBUTE TO BILLIE HOLIDAY,' on Sunday at two Bronx locations. At 2 p.m., Van Cortlandt Park, Rockwood Drive, near Mosholu Avenue; at 4 p.m., Fordham University, Bronx Rose Hill Campus, Southern Boulevard. With the Bronx Arts Ensemble and soloists. Free; take seating. Information: (718)601-7399. GHI BRONX TENNIS CLASSIC, Crotona Park, East 173rd Street and Crotona Avenue, Crotona Park, the Bronx. Continues tomorrow with semifinal singles and doubles matches from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. and tennis lessons with professional players from the New York Junior Tennis League from noon to 3 p.m.; all are free. On Sunday, finals matches will run from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; admission: $10; under 12, free. Information: (718)294-2573; www.nyjtl.org. BROOKLYN WATERFRONT ARTISTS COALITION, PIER ART SHOW 12, Red Hook Pier, 499 Van Brunt Street, Red Hook, Brooklyn. Through Sunday, ''The Earth Art Show,'' with works large and small. Tomorrow and Sunday, noon to 6 p.m. Free. Information: (718)596-2507. 'OTHER ISLANDS OF NEW YORK CRUISE,' a look at some of the islands that dot the New York waterway, including Ellis, Hoffman and Swinburne Islands, meeting Sunday at 9:30 a.m. at the foot of Old Fulton Street in Brooklyn and the East River, opposite the River Cafe. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee: $45; $35 for members, students and 63+. Reservations: (718)788-8500, ext. 219.

headline: A Book to Read Carefully, With a Physical Therapist Near
summary: ''Hunger's Brides,'' Paul Anderson's debut novel, is certain to be one of the biggest books of the fall. The question is how many readers will want to do the heavy lifting required to read it. At 1,360 pages (not counting 8 pages of titles and contents at the beginning of the book and 8 blank pages at the end, presumably added for production reasons) the book, quite simply, is massive. It weighs 4 pounds, 9 ounces, equivalent to two and a half copies of ''The Da Vinci Code,'' and it is thicker than Verizon's Manhattan telephone directory (either the white or yellow pages).

summary: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it would start selling high-speed Internet connections for $14.95 a month to attract customers with slower dial-up connections and to compete with cable companies. The company also formed a marketing alliance with Yahoo, which has created a Web portal for Verizon customers. This largely displaces a similar deal Verizon had with Microsoft for MSN to be its Web portal.

headline: Wireless Firms Seek Big Deal: Cellular System For the Subway
summary: The decision to introduce cellphone service in the city's underground subway stations touched off a flurry of interest in the telecommunications industry yesterday, as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority began soliciting bids for a 10-year contract that will involve immense technical complexity and probably be worth $50 million to $100 million. Representatives of the country's four largest wireless companies -- Cingular Wireless, Verizon Wireless, Sprint Nextel and T-Mobile -- all said yesterday that they were considering submitting proposals to build the wireless voice and data network, which will cover 277 of the city's 468 stations. Companies that make wireless hardware -- cables, radios and antennas -- also expressed interest. Bids are due on Oct. 12.

Meets tomorrow and Sunday at 10:30 a.m. and 1, 3:30 and 7 p.m.; and Monday at 10:30 a.m., 1 and 3:30 p.m. in front of the Lincoln Statue in Union Square Park, 17th Street and Broadway. Fee, $15. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888)377-4455. 'FIVE BRIDGES AND A TRAM CAR RIDE,' a 12-mile excursion through Queens, Manhattan, Brooklyn and Roosevelt Island, meeting tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. in Manhattan in front of McDonald's, Second Avenue and 57th Street. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Fee, $3; tram fare additional. Information: (212)348-5344. FREE TOURS OF CENTRAL PARK Tomorrow at 11 a.m., ''Conservatory Garden,'' covers its history and design, meeting at the main entrance, Fifth Avenue and 105th Street. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''Manhattan Adirondacks,'' the vision of the Adirondack Mountains by the Central Park designers Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, meeting at the Dana Discovery Center, inside the park at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street. Sunday at noon, ''A Road Once Traveled,'' a look at the role of Central Park in the American Revolution and the War of 1812, meeting at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center. Information: (212)360-2726. BROOKLYN BRIDGE AND SKYLINE AT TWILIGHT BIKE TOUR , a nine-mile ride along the Greenway and the Wall Street area sponsored by Bike the Big Apple. Sunday and Monday at 4:30 p.m. Fee, $49. All equipment provided. Reservations and meeting place: (877)865-0078; bikethebigapple.com. BRAZILIAN INDEPENDENCE DAY Museum of the Moving Image, 36-01 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. The event will be celebrated with screenings of the 2005 documentary ''Favela Rising,'' directed by Jeff Zimbalist and Matt Mochary tonight at 7:30 and 9:30, as well as food and live music beginning at 6. Admission, $10; 65+ and students, $7.50; 5 to 18, $5; free for members. Information: www.movingimage.us or (718)784-0077. BAHAMAS CULTURE DAY, Pier 63 Maritime, West 23rd Street and the Hudson River, Chelsea. With Bahamian music, dance, food and crafts. Sunday, noon to midnight. Sponsored by the Bahamian American Cultural Society. Information: (212)213-0562. LATIN MUSIC FESTIVAL AT ORCHARD BEACH, Section 9, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx. A free event with El Canario and Los Hermanos Moreno. Sunday at noon. Part of Sundays at Orchard Beach. Sponsored by Heineken, Verizon and other corporations. Information: (718)885-2275. SHAKESPEARE PROJECT, sponsors free outdoor performances through Sept. 24 at various locations around the city. ''Romeo and Juliet'' by the New Perspectives Theater Company, tonight at 6 in Sunset Park, 41st Street to 44th and Fifth Avenue to Seventh, Brooklyn; and tomorrow at 2 and 5 p.m. in Fort Tryon Park, 190th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, Washington Heights. ''Twelfth Night: Illyrium Delirium'' by the Aisling Arts Ensemble tonight at 6 in Marcus Garvey Park, Fifth Avenue and 125th Street, East Harlem; and Sunday at 2 and 5 p.m. in Fort Tryon Park. Information: www.playoutside.org. HENRY ISOLA CROSS-COUNTRY CLASSIC, a four-mile run in Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, Sunday at 11:30 a.m. Sign-in at Broadway and 252nd Street. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners. Race-day registration only: $7; 14 and younger, $5. Information: (212) 860-4455; www.nyrrc.org. Upstate New York GREEN CORN WEEKEND, Philipsburg Manor, 381 North Broadway, Sleepy Hollow. A celebration of Native American culture, with music, dance, crafts and food. Tomorrow through Monday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Part of Historic Hudson Valley. Admission, $10; students and 62+, $9; 5 to 17, $6; under 5 and members, free. Information: (914)631-8200. NEW YORK RENAISSANCE FAIRE, Sterling Forest, 600 Route 17A, Tuxedo. Tomorrow through Monday, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m., and weekends through Sept. 25. Admission, $19; 5 to 12, $9; under 5, free. Information: (845) 351-5174; www.renfair.com. WOODSTOCK/NEW PALTZ ARTS & CRAFTS, Ulster County Fairgrounds, Libertyville Road, New Paltz. Tomorrow and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Monday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission, $8; 62+, $7; 4 to 12, $4.50. Information: www.quailhollow.com. CHESS TOURNAMENT, John Jay Homestead State Historic Site, 400 Route 22, Katonah. Open to all players; participants should provided their own chessboards, chess sets and clocks. Also presented by the Max Pavey Chess Club. Monday, beginning at 9:30 a.m.; free registration begins at 9 a.m. House tours will be given from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; fee, $7; 65+, $5; 2 to 12, $2. Information: (914)232-5651. 22ND LASDON LABOR DAY ANTIQUES FAIR, Lasdon Park and Arboretum, Route 35, Katonah. Monday, 10 a.m to 5 p.m. Admission, $6. No dogs allowed in park. Information: (914) 273-4667. HUDSON VALLEY SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL Boscobel Restoration, 1601 Route 9D, Garrison. ''The Two Gentleman of Verona.'' Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Sunday at 6 p.m. Tickets, $32 to $38. Information: Information: (845)265-3638. New Jersey ROCKIN' OLDIES WINE FESTIVAL, Waterloo Village, 525 Waterloo Road, Stanhope. Sampling of wines from 15 wineries, food, music and children's activities. Tomorrow and Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. Sponsored by the Garden State Wine Growers Association. Admission, $18; 16 to 20, $10; under 16, free. Information: (609)588-0085; www.newjerseywines.com. OCEAN CITY POPS, Ocean City High School, Sixth Street and Atlantic Avenue, Ocean City. A classical concert. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets $15. Information: (609)525-9248. MUSIC AND FIREWORKS, Point Pleasant Beach. A performance by the Orchestra of St. Peter by the Sea. Monday night at 7:30; spectators should provide their own seating. Donations accepted. Information: (732)920-4444. Long Island OLDE TIME MUSIC WEEKEND, Village Restoration, Round Swamp Road, Old Bethpage. Tomorrow through Monday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; 4 to 14 and 60+, $5; under 4, free. Information: (516)572-8400. 2005 BYZANTINE BAZAAR LONG ISLAND'S SLAVIC FOLK FESTIVAL, Church of the Resurrection, Edgewater and Mayflower Avenues, Smithtown. Today through Monday, 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. Information: (631)724-0780 or (631)835-8112. FIFTH ANNUAL SUMMER FAIR, Hampton Bays Elementary School, 72 Ponquogue Avenue, Hampton Bays. Tomorrow and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Information: (631)723-1684. ANNUAL GREAT TOMATO TASTE-OFF, Quail Hill Community Farm, Apple Orchard, Side Lane and Deep Hill Lane, Amagansett. Samplings of 55 varieties of tomatoes. Tomorrow, 9 a.m. to noon. Donation, $5. Information: (631)283-3195. SHINNECOCK INDIAN POW-WOW Shinnecock Reservation, off Montauk Highway in Southampton. With dance shows and drum contests featuring more than 40 tribes from the United States and Central and South America. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. Also Sunday, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. and Monday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. $10 for adults; $7 for those 6 to 12 and 65+, free for those 5 and younger. Information: (516)283-6143. B.B. KING BLUES FESTIVAL, Brookhaven Amphitheater, South Bicycle Path, Farmingville. With the blues guitarist and others. Sunday at 6 p.m. Tickets, $25 to $45. Information: (631)451-8010. ANNUAL HAMPTON CLASSIC HORSE SHOW, 240 Snake Hollow Road, Bridgehampton. Today through Sunday with competitions beginning at 8 a.m. each day. Tickets, $10 to $20. Information: (631)537-3177. Connecticut ROLEX VINTAGE CAR FESTIVAL, Lime Rock Park, 497 Lime Rock Road, Lakeville. Presented by BMW with demonstrations, exhibits and a display of classic cars. Today through Monday, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. Gates open each day at 7 a.m. Tickets: $15 to $75. Information: (800)722-3577. 145TH WOODSTOCK FAIR, Woodstock Fairgrounds, Routes 169 and 171, South Woodstock. Today through Sunday, 9 to 9, Monday, 9 to 6; $10; 12 and younger, free. Information (860)928-3246. CRAFTS ON THE GREEN, Sherman Green, Post Road, Fairfield. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Sponsored by The Fairfield County Alumnae Chapter of Delta Zeta. Information: (203)335-8151. 45TH ANNUAL MARK TWAIN LIBRARY BOOK FAIR, Redding Community Center, 27 Lonetown Road (behind Redding Elementary School), Redding. More than 50,000 books. Today, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; tomorrow, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Monday, 9 a.m. to noon (free books available). Information: (203)938-2545. SCHOONER INC., Long Wharf, New Haven. An exploration of the biology and history of the Long Island sound aboard the Quinnipiack. Today, 6 to 9 p.m., and Sunday, 1 to 4 p.m. and 5 to 8 p.m. Admission, $25, 12 and younger, $10. Information: (203)865-1737. STEAM TRAIN AND RIVERBOAT RIDES, 1 Railroad Avenue, Essex. Tomorrow and Sunday, ''Caboose Weekend,'' with rides aboard the caboose for an additional $5 (which benefits the Friends of the Valley Railroad). Daily through Monday at 11 a.m. and 12:30, 2 and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: Train and boat, $24; 3 to 11, $12; train only, $16; 3 to 11, $8. Information: (800)377-3987. GOSHEN AGRICULTURAL FAIR, Route 63, Goshen. With farm animals for judging, fruit, vegetables, and exhibitions. Special features: tomorrow, horse show, 8:30 a.m.; pony-drawing, 1 p.m.; Sunday, wood-chopping, noon; and Monday, oxen-pulling, noon. Admission, $6; under 12, free. Information: (860)491-3655.

headline: In Complex Office Deals, He's Mr. Big
summary: FOR another commercial real estate broker, it would have been the deal of a lifetime. In March, Robert J. Alexander and his team at CB Richard Ellis arranged the $505 million sale of Verizon's headquarters, on the Avenue of the Americas near 42nd Street in Midtown Manhattan, to Equity Office Properties Trust, the nation's largest office real estate investment trust. At the same time, as part of Verizon's consolidation efforts, he helped the company buy the old AT&T headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J., for $100 million. Next, Equity Office hired him and his team to act as leasing agent for the former Verizon headquarters, with 1.1 million square feet of space. But the trifecta, which stands to generate millions in commissions for CB Richard Ellis, is merely the latest coup for Mr. Alexander, 50, whose heavy-hitter status and physical stature -- he is 6-foot-2 and still has the shoulders of the high school defensive end he once was -- have earned him the nickname Mr. Big.
